contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (d) if subsection 8(2) applies and the medicine: (i) includes one or more active ingredients, the name of which includes descriptors (for example chemical salts or hydration states) that are not therapeutically relevant; and (ii) the name and quantity or proportion of each of those active ingredients is displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), then the name of the therapeutically active moiety(ies) of the active ingredient may be displayed on the main label on the primary pack, instead of the name of the active ingredient, if: (iii) this is in a text size of not less than 3.0 millimetres; and (iv) no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients in the medicine.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (f) The presentation of the critical health information, and any information mentioned in paragraphs 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) that is included, must be presented in black or other dark coloured texts, using only one colour, on a white or other contrasting background.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient with a therapeutically irrelevant descriptor in its name, and the name and quantity of this active ingredient is displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), can the name of the therapeutically active moiety be displayed on the main label instead of the active ingredient name if it is in a text size of 2.5 millimetres and no quantity information is displayed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 9(7)(d), if a medicine contains an active ingredient whose name includes therapeutically irrelevant descriptors, and the name and quantity are displayed per subsection 8(2), the therapeutically active moiety name can only be displayed instead of the active ingredient name if the text size is at least 3.0 millimetres and no quantity information is displayed for any active ingredients. A 2.5 millimetre text size does not meet the minimum 3.0 millimetre requirement specified in 9(7)(d)(iii).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label includes critical health information and other information mentioned in 8(2)(c), (d) or (e), and this is all presented in red text on a white background, does this comply with the presentation requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 8(2)(f) states that critical health information and any information from 8(2)(c), (d) or (e) must be presented in black or other dark coloured text, using only one colour, on a white or contrasting background. Using red text does not meet the requirement to use black or dark coloured text specified in 8(2)(f).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains multiple active ingredients, some with therapeutically irrelevant descriptors in their names, and the names and quantities are displayed per 8(2), can the therapeutically active moiety names be displayed instead of the active ingredient names in 4.0 millimetre text if quantities are shown for some but not all active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(7)(d) allows displaying therapeutically active moiety names instead of active ingredient names if the active ingredient names include irrelevant descriptors and are displayed with quantities per 8(2). However, this is only allowed if the moiety names are in at least 3.0 millimetre text and no quantities are displayed for any active ingredients, per 9(7)(d)(iii) and (iv). Displaying quantities for some ingredients violates the requirement in 9(7)(d)(iv) that no quantities be shown.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label presents critical health information in blue text on a yellow background, and also includes other information from 8(2)(c) presented in black text on white, does the label comply with the presentation requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per 8(2)(f), critical health information and any 8(2)(c), (d) or (e) information included must be presented in black or dark coloured text, using only one colour, on a white or contrasting background. Using blue text on yellow for the critical information and a different black on white scheme for the 8(2)(c) information violates the 8(2)(f) requirement to use only one text colour for all of this information.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (c) (i) the total number of active ingredients in the different formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit are to be counted; and (ii) if the same active ingredient is contained in two or more formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit, each of those active ingredients is to be counted separately, for the purposes of determining if paragraph 9(6)(b) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit, or which paragraph in subsection 9(7) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit; and

9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (d) if subsection 8(2) applies and the medicine: (i) includes one or more active ingredients, the name of which includes descriptors (for example chemical salts or hydration states) that are not therapeutically relevant; and (ii) the name and quantity or proportion of each of those active ingredients is displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), then the name of the therapeutically active moiety(ies) of the active ingredient may be displayed on the main label on the primary pack, instead of the name of the active ingredient, if: (iii) this is in a text size of not less than 3.0 millimetres; and (iv) no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients in the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a composite pack or medicine kit containing two formulations with the same active ingredient, and the medicine is intended to be registered goods, how many times should that active ingredient be counted for the purposes of determining which paragraph in subsection 9(7) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The active ingredient should be counted twice.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(8)(c)(ii), if the same active ingredient is contained in two or more formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit, each of those active ingredients is to be counted separately for the purposes of determining which paragraph in subsection 9(7) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit. Therefore, if a composite pack or medicine kit contains two formulations with the same active ingredient, that active ingredient should be counted twice.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and includes an active ingredient whose name includes a non-therapeutically relevant descriptor, under what conditions can the name of the therapeutically active moiety be displayed on the main label instead of the active ingredient name?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the therapeutically active moiety can be displayed instead of the active ingredient name if the name and quantity or proportion of the active ingredient is displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), the therapeutically active moiety name is in a text size of at least 3.0 millimetres, and no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(d) states that if subsection 8(2) applies and the medicine includes an active ingredient whose name includes a non-therapeutically relevant descriptor, and the name and quantity or proportion of that active ingredient is displayed per subsection 8(2), then the therapeutically active moiety name may be displayed instead of the active ingredient name if it is in a text size of at least 3.0 millimetres and no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any active ingredients.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a composite pack with three formulations each containing a different active ingredient, and the medicine is intended to be registered goods, which paragraph in subsection 9(7) would apply for determining the labelling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Paragraph 9(7)(c) would apply for determining the labelling requirements.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(c)(i) states that for a composite pack or medicine kit, the total number of active ingredients in the different formulations are to be counted for the purposes of determining which paragraph in subsection 9(7) applies. With three formulations each containing a different active ingredient, the total count of active ingredients is three. Therefore, paragraph 9(7)(c), which covers medicines with 3 or more active ingredients, would apply in determining the labelling requirements for this composite pack.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and includes multiple active ingredients, one of which has a name that includes a non-therapeutically relevant chemical salt, under what conditions would displaying the therapeutically active moiety name instead of that active ingredient name on the main label be prohibited?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Displaying the therapeutically active moiety name instead of the active ingredient name on the main label would be prohibited if the name and quantity or proportion of that active ingredient is not displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), or if any quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients in the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(d) allows the therapeutically active moiety name to be displayed instead of an active ingredient name that includes a non-therapeutically relevant descriptor only if the name and quantity or proportion of that active ingredient is displayed per subsection 8(2), and no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any active ingredients. Therefore, if either of those conditions is not met, displaying the therapeutically active moiety name in place of the active ingredient name would be prohibited.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (f) The presentation of the critical health information, and any information mentioned in paragraphs 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) that is included, must be presented in black or other dark coloured texts, using only one colour, on a white or other contrasting background.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label includes critical health information and additional information about storage conditions, what color and background must the critical health information be presented on, and where must the storage conditions information be placed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The critical health information must be in black or dark colored text on a white or contrasting background. The storage conditions must be under an 'Other information' heading below the critical information.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(f) states that critical health information must be presented in black or dark text on a white or contrasting background. Section 8(2)(e) states that additional information like storage conditions must be under an 'Other information' heading that follows below the critical information headings mentioned in 8(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Given a medicine label that contains critical health information, the names of inactive ingredients, and distributor contact details, what color must the critical information text be in, and under what heading must the ingredient and contact information be placed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The critical health information must be in black or another dark color. The inactive ingredients and distributor contact details must be under an 'Other information' heading or other appropriate heading below the critical information.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per 8(2)(f), critical health information must use black or dark colored text. 8(2)(e) states that information other than the critical health information, like excipient names and distributor details, must go under an 'Other information' or other appropriate heading that follows below the critical information headings from 8(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a medicine label includes critical health information in blue text, along with a list of inactive ingredients. Assuming no other information is included, does this labeling comply with the regulations?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, this labeling does not comply. The critical health information must be in black or dark text, not blue. Additionally, the list of inactive ingredients must be under an 'Other information' or other appropriate heading below the critical information.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 8(2)(f) requires critical information to use black or dark text, so blue is not compliant. 8(2)(e) states inactive ingredients must be under a heading like 'Other information' below the critical information, which is also not satisfied here.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a medicine label containing critical health information, storage instructions, and sponsor contact details, with the storage and contact information under an 'Additional Details' heading below the critical information. Assuming the critical information uses red text on a white background, does the label meet the regulations?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, this label does not meet the regulations. While placing the storage instructions and sponsor contact under an appropriate 'Additional Details' heading below the critical information complies with 8(2)(e), using red text for the critical information violates 8(2)(f) which requires black or dark colored text.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 8(2)(e) is satisfied by having the storage and sponsor contact information under an appropriate heading below the critical information. However, 8(2)(f) specifies critical information must use black or dark text on a white or contrasting background, so red text is non-compliant.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (c) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (1) Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order, the information on the main label of the medicine must include: (c) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains 5 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, is it required to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(7)(c), if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Paragraph 9(1)(c) states that the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients must be included on the main label. Therefore, since the medicine has 5 active ingredients, it is exempt from the requirement to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label, assuming subsection 8(2) applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains 3 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, is it required to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(1)(c) states that the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine must be included on the main label, subject to the qualifications in section 9. Section 9(7)(c) provides an exemption from 9(1)(c) if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies. Since this medicine only contains 3 active ingredients, the exemption in 9(7)(c) does not apply, so the general requirement in 9(1)(c) to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label still applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming subsection 8(2) does not apply, if a medicine contains 6 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, is it required to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(1)(c) requires the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients to be included on the main label, subject to the qualifications in section 9. Section 9(7)(c) provides an exemption from this requirement if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies. However, this question states that subsection 8(2) does not apply. Therefore, even though the medicine contains more than four active ingredients, the exemption in 9(7)(c) does not apply, so the general requirement in 9(1)(c) to include the quantities or proportions on the label still applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming subsection 8(2) applies, if a medicine contains 2 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, is it required to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(1)(c) states that the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients must be included on the main label of registered goods, subject to the qualifications in section 9. Section 9(7)(c) provides an exemption from this requirement if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies. In this case, even though subsection 8(2) applies, the medicine only contains 2 active ingredients, which is less than four. Therefore, the exemption in 9(7)(c) does not apply, so the general requirement in 9(1)(c) to include the quantity or proportion of active ingredients on the label still applies.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (b) If, in relation to a medicine referred to in (a) there are: (i) four or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods; or (ii) two or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods, then, in relation to compliance of the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the following information is displayed: (iii) the name of the medicine; and (iv) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and (v) the expiry date of the medicine preceded by the expiry date prefix; and (vi) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

9 Information to be included on the main label (6) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods: (a) if the medicine is a sunscreen preparation - the name of every active ingredient, together with the quantity or proportion of every active ingredient, and the name of the dosage form, may appear on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and contains 5 active ingredients, what information must be displayed on the label of the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine, batch number preceded by the batch number prefix, expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix, and the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(i) states that for a medicine intended to be registered goods with four or more active ingredients, the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack label must display the information listed in 10(9)(b)(iii) through (vi) to comply with sections 8 and 9. This includes the medicine name, batch number with prefix, expiry date with prefix, and sponsor/distributor name or identifying trademark.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a sunscreen preparation medicine is intended to be listed goods, can the name and quantity of every active ingredient appear on a side or rear panel or label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, for a sunscreen preparation medicine intended to be listed goods, the name of every active ingredient, quantity of every active ingredient, and dosage form name may appear on a side panel, side label, rear panel or rear label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(6)(a) explicitly states that if a medicine is intended to be listed goods and is a sunscreen preparation, the name, quantity and proportion of every active ingredient, along with the dosage form name, may appear on a side panel, side label, rear panel or rear label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be listed goods and contains 3 active ingredients, what information must be displayed on the label of the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine must display the name of the medicine, batch number preceded by the batch number prefix, expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix, and the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(ii) states that for a medicine intended to be listed goods with two or more active ingredients, the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack label must display the information listed in 10(9)(b)(iii) through (vi) to comply with sections 8 and 9. This includes the medicine name, batch number with prefix, expiry date with prefix, and sponsor/distributor name or identifying trademark.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is not a sunscreen preparation and is intended to be listed goods, can the name and quantity of every active ingredient appear on a side or rear panel or label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, section 9(6)(a) only allows the active ingredient names, quantities, proportions and dosage form name to appear on side or rear panels/labels for sunscreen preparation medicines intended to be listed goods. Other listed medicines cannot use this labeling exception.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(6)(a) specifically limits the allowance for active ingredient details to appear on side or rear panels/labels to sunscreen preparation medicines intended to be listed goods. By omission, this labeling is not permitted for non-sunscreen listed medicines per the information provided in sections 9 and 10.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (5) Sunscreen preparations If: (b) is enclosed in a container with a capacity of not more than 25 millilitres, then, in relation to compliance with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if (i) the sun protection factor is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres; and (ii) all other information is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.0 millimetres.

9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a sunscreen preparation that comes in a container of 20 millilitres capacity, what is the minimum text size required for displaying the sun protection factor and all other information on the label to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The minimum text size required is 1.5 millimetres for the sun protection factor and 1.0 millimetres for all other information.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(b) states that for sunscreen preparations in containers of not more than 25 millilitres capacity, to comply with sections 8 and 9, the sun protection factor must be displayed in a text size of at least 1.5 millimetres and all other information must be at least 1.0 millimetres. Since the given container is 20 millilitres, these minimum text size requirements apply.

QuestionAnswers.Question: On the main label of a medicine, is it permitted for any text or graphics to separate the name of the medicine from the name(s) of active ingredient(s)? If so, under what conditions?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, text or graphics can separate the medicine name and active ingredient name(s) in specific cases allowed by the regulation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(3)(b) generally prohibits any text or graphics from separating the medicine name and active ingredient name(s) on the main label. However, it allows exceptions where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by paragraph 11(2)(h), subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A), or subsection 11(5); or (ii) related to identifying different formulations in a composite pack or medicine kit. In these specific cases, text or graphics may appear between the medicine and active ingredient names.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a sunscreen preparation is in a 30 millilitre container. What minimum text sizes are required on the label for the sun protection factor and other information in order to be compliant with the relevant regulations?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The standard minimum text size requirements in sections 8 and 9 apply, as the container exceeds 25 millilitres capacity.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(b) allows reduced minimum text sizes of 1.5mm for sun protection factor and 1.0mm for other information, but only for sunscreen containers of not more than 25 millilitres. Since this container is 30 millilitres, the special provision does not apply. The label must follow the normal minimum text size requirements set out in sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Under what circumstances does the regulation permit text or graphics to appear between the medicine name and active ingredient name(s) on the main label, if that text or graphics relates to identifying different formulations contained in the product?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Text or graphics identifying different formulations may appear between the medicine and active ingredient names if the product is a composite pack or medicine kit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(3)(b)(ii) allows text or graphics to separate the medicine name from the active ingredient name(s) on the main label when that additional information is related to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained specifically in a composite pack or a medicine kit. For other types of products, this text or graphics would not be permitted in that position on the label.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (b) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and the quantities or proportions of the active ingredients may be included on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label, when displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains 5 active ingredients and is registered goods, can the names and quantities of the active ingredients be included on a side or rear panel if displayed in a text size of 2.5 millimetres or greater?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(b) states that if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and is registered goods, then the names and quantities of the active ingredients may be included on a side panel, side label, rear panel or rear label, when displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes 'Other information' after the critical health information, can it contain details about the medicine's dosage under this heading?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) specifies that if information other than critical health information is included under the 'Other information' heading, it must not contain any additional information other than requirements relating to storage conditions, information about tamper evident packaging, names of excipients, and sponsor or distributor contact details. Dosage information is not permitted under this heading.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a registered non-prescription medicine has 6 active ingredients, is it mandatory to include the names and quantities of the active ingredients on a side or rear panel in a minimum 2.5mm text size?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(b) states that for registered goods with four or more active ingredients, the names and quantities 'may be' included on a side or rear panel in minimum 2.5mm text size. The word 'may' indicates this is optional, not mandatory, even if the medicine has more than 4 active ingredients.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming information about a non-prescription medicine's storage conditions is included on the label under the 'Other information' heading, can the sponsor contact details also be included under this same heading?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) allows certain types of information to be included under the 'Other information' heading, including both storage condition requirements and sponsor or distributor contact details. Therefore, both of these pieces of information can be grouped together under this one heading.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "critical health information" means information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) of this Order, that is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (c) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label only includes the quantity of active ingredients but no other information, would it be compliant with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 8(1)(c) requires the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients to be on the label. However, section 6 defines 'critical health information' as also requiring the information from paragraphs 8(1)(b), (j), (k), (l) and (n). Therefore, only including the quantity of active ingredients is not sufficient for compliance.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a non-prescription medicine label includes all the information required by paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n), can any of that information be omitted?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines the information required by paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) as 'critical health information'. Paragraph 8(1) requires this information to be included on the label, subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10. Therefore, unless allowed by those other provisions, the information cannot be omitted.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming no other regulation sections apply, is the percentage of active ingredients in a non-prescription medicine required on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 8(1)(c) requires 'the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients' to be on the label. 'Proportion' includes percentages. Section 6 defines this as part of the 'critical health information'. Therefore, subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10, the percentage is required on the label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a non-prescription medicine label is compliant with all aspects of the regulation except paragraph 8(1)(k), is it fully compliant overall?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines the information required by paragraph 8(1)(k) as part of the 'critical health information' that is required for safe use. Paragraph 8(1) requires this 'critical health information' on the label, subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10. Therefore, omitting the 8(1)(k) information means the label is not fully compliant.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (g) for preparations applied to the skin and mucous membranes, other than those covered by paragraph (f) - as a percentage expressed in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate, or as the weight or volume in a stated weight or volume of the medicine, as appropriate;

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (f) for pressurised metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products such as nasal sprays, the quantity of the active ingredient is: (i) the quantity delivered per actuation; or where the Secretary, when registering the medicine, has accepted that the dose of products containing those active ingredients was clinically established as the metered dose, then: (ii) the quantity metered per actuation;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a pressurized metered dose inhaler that contains an active ingredient where the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when the medicine was registered, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity metered per actuation
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(ii), for pressurized metered dose inhalers where the Secretary accepted that the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when registering the medicine, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a cream applied to the skin, how should the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: As a percentage expressed in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate, or as the weight or volume in a stated weight or volume of the medicine, as appropriate
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(g), for preparations applied to the skin and mucous membranes other than pressurized metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient must be expressed as a percentage in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate, or as the weight or volume in a stated weight or volume of the medicine, as appropriate.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a nasal spray and the Secretary accepted the dose as the quantity delivered per actuation when the medicine was registered, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity delivered per actuation
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(i), for pressurized metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products such as nasal sprays, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a dry powder inhaler containing an active ingredient where the Secretary did not accept the dose as the metered dose when the medicine was registered, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity delivered per actuation
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(i), for pressurized metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation, unless section 11(2)(f)(ii) applies. Since the Secretary did not accept the dose as the metered dose when the medicine was registered, section 11(2)(f)(ii) does not apply, so the quantity should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation per section 11(2)(f)(i).

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (8) Individually wrapped medicines (c) Where: (i) a medicine consists of dry herbs contained in individual bags and the bag is retained around the herbs during preparation; (ii) the bags are contained in a primary pack, the label of which complies with the requirements of this Order, then the individual bag need not be labelled with the information referred to in sections 8 and 9.
9 Information to be included on the main label (10) Subsection 9(9) does not apply: (a) where the medicine is supplied in a small container; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assume there is a dry herb medicine consisting of individual bags of herbs that are retained during preparation, and the bags are contained in a primary pack. If the primary pack label complies with sections 8 and 9, does the individual bag also need to be labelled with the information from sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 10(8)(c), if a medicine consists of dry herbs in individual bags that are retained during preparation, and the bags are in a primary pack with a label that complies with sections 8 and 9, then the individual bags do not need to be labelled with the information from sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assume a medicine is supplied in a small container. Does the exception in section 9(10)(a) apply to the labelling requirements in section 9(9)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(10)(a) states that subsection 9(9) does not apply where the medicine is supplied in a small container. Therefore, the labelling requirements in 9(9) do not need to be followed for medicines in small containers, as per the exception in 9(10)(a).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assume a dry herb medicine has individual herb bags without labels, and the bags are in a primary pack. If the primary pack label does not comply with sections 8 and 9, can the individual bags be unlabelled as per section 10(8)(c)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(c) allows individual bags of dry herb medicines to be unlabelled only if the primary pack label complies with the requirements of sections 8 and 9. If the primary pack label does not comply with sections 8 and 9, then the exception in 10(8)(c) does not apply, and the individual bags must be labelled.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assume a medicine is supplied in a small container, and it consists of dry herbs in individual bags that are retained during preparation. Do the individual bags need to be labelled with the information from sections 8 and 9 if the primary pack label complies with those sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 10(8)(c), if the dry herb medicine bags are in a primary pack with a label complying with sections 8 and 9, the individual bags do not need that information on their labels. Additionally, section 9(10)(a) provides an exception to 9(9) labelling requirements for medicines in small containers. Therefore, the individual bags do not require the labelling from sections 8 and 9, considering both 10(8)(c) and 9(10)(a).

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (5) If the medicine contains: (c) if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and (i) subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names, and quantities or proportions, of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or (ii) subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

9 Information to be included on the main label (1) Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order, the information on the main label of the medicine must include: (c) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and contains active ingredients, what are the requirements for displaying the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients on the label if subsection 8(2) does not apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(5)(c)(i), if the medicine is intended to be registered goods, contains active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, is compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) required?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: As per section 9(5)(c)(ii), if the medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the qualifications and special requirements specified in sections 9 and 10 do not apply, what information must be included on the main label of a medicine regarding the active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine must be included on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(1)(c) states that subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in sections 9 and 10, the information on the main label of the medicine must include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods, contains active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, is it necessary to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label as per section 9(1)(c)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, it is not necessary to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label as per section 9(1)(c).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(i) specifies that if the medicine is intended to be registered goods, contains active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres. This overrides the requirement in section 9(1)(c) to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (a) Subject to paragraph (b), if: (i) a medicine consists of individual dosage units such as tablets, capsules, pills, pastilles, cachets, lozenges, pessaries, suppositories or single doses of powder; and (ii) two or more dosage units are individually enclosed in a strip, blister or dial dispenser pack such that the dosage units can only be extracted individually; and (iii) the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack is enclosed in a primary pack, the label of which complies with sections 8 and 9, then, in relation to compliance of the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the following information is displayed: (iv) the name of the medicine; and (v) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and (vi) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and (vii) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and (viii) the expiry date of the medicine preceded by the expiry date prefix; and (ix) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

9 Information to be included on the main label (9) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and the name of an active ingredient included in the medicine comprises an ingredient name specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, then the names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of individual dosage units enclosed in a blister pack, which is then enclosed in a primary pack with a label that complies with sections 8 and 9, what information must be displayed on the label of the blister pack itself to be compliant with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine, the name(s) and quantity/proportion of all active ingredients, the batch number and expiry date with their respective prefixes, and the name of the sponsor/distributor or their registered trademark.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) specifies that if the conditions in (i), (ii) and (iii) are met regarding dosage units in a blister pack enclosed in a compliant primary pack, then the blister pack label only needs to display the information listed in (iv) through (ix) to be compliant with sections 8 and 9. This includes the medicine name, active ingredient names and quantities, batch number and expiry date with prefixes, and sponsor/distributor information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a registered medicine where the name of an active ingredient comprises an ingredient name specified in Schedule 2 to this Order. What is the minimum text size that must be used to display the names and quantities of all active ingredients on the main label, as per the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimeters.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(9) directly states that if a registered medicine has an active ingredient name specified in Schedule 2, then the names of all active ingredients and their quantities must be displayed on the main label in a text size of at least 2.5 millimeters to comply with the regulation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Supposing an over-the-counter medicine is packaged with individual tablets in a blister pack, which is then put inside a primary carton with fully compliant labeling. The active ingredient is listed in Schedule 2. What information needs to be on the blister pack label, and in what minimum text size?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The blister pack label needs to show the medicine name, all active ingredient names and quantities, batch number and expiry date with prefixes, and sponsor/distributor information, as per section 10(9)(a)(iv)-(ix). The active ingredient name and quantity must be in a minimum 2.5 mm text size, as required by section 9(9) for Schedule 2 ingredients.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) allows reduced labeling on a blister pack if it is inside a fully labeled primary pack. Only the information in 10(9)(a)(iv)-(ix) is required. However, section 9(9) mandates a minimum 2.5 mm text size for active ingredient details for Schedule 2 ingredients, which still applies to the blister pack label. So the blister label must have the 10(9)(a)(iv)-(ix) information, with active ingredients in 2.5+ mm text.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered medicine sold in single dose sachets packed inside a primary carton, is it acceptable for the sachets to omit the name and quantity of a minor active ingredient as long as it is declared on the outer carton label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, this is not acceptable. The sachet labels must include the names and quantities of all active ingredients, even if they are also on the primary pack label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) specifies that for medicine in individual dosage units like sachets packed in a primary pack, the sachet labels can have reduced information and still comply with sections 8 and 9. However, 10(9)(a)(v) and (vi) clearly state that the names and quantities of all active ingredients must still be on the sachet labels. Section 9(9) also requires this information for registered medicines with Schedule 2 ingredients. The active ingredient details cannot be omitted from the sachets.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (1) Preparations for ophthalmic use In addition to the requirements of sections 8 and 9 above, if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use, the label on the container and on the primary pack or, where subsection 10(7) applies, the primary pack, must include: (c) if the medicine is for multidose use - a statement to the effect that ‘the medicine should not be used more than four weeks’, or such shorter period as specified in the approved product details in relation to the medicine, after the container is first opened;

10 Qualifications and special requirements (7) Small containers If: (d) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, unless there are four or more active ingredients; and the following information is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres:

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use and is for multidose use, what is the maximum time the medicine can be used after first opening the container if no shorter period is specified in the approved product details?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 4 weeks
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(c) states that if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use and is for multidose use, the label must include a statement that the medicine should not be used more than four weeks after the container is first opened, unless a shorter period is specified in the approved product details.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a small container of medicine with four or more active ingredients, is it required to list the names of all active ingredients on the label if the conditions in section 10(7) are met?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(7)(d) states that for small containers meeting the conditions in 10(7), the names of all active ingredients are not required on the label if there are four or more active ingredients.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is in a small container that meets the conditions in section 10(7), what is the minimum text size required for displaying the information listed in 10(7)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 1.5 millimetres
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The last part of section 10(7) states that for small containers meeting the conditions, the information listed must be displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a multidose ophthalmic medicine in a small container meeting the conditions of 10(7), is a statement about the maximum time the medicine can be used after opening required to be on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(c) requires the maximum usage time after opening statement for all multidose ophthalmic medicines. Section 10(7) provides some labeling exemptions for small containers but does not exempt the requirement from 10(1)(c). Therefore, the maximum usage time statement is still required even for small containers of multidose ophthalmic medicines.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, what information is not required to be displayed on the label according to section 9(5)(c)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients are not required to be displayed on the side or rear panel or label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(5)(c)(ii), if the medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. This means the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients do not need to be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in this case.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains active ingredients and is not intended to be registered goods, what text size must the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients be displayed in on the side or rear panel or label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(i) states that if the medicine contains active ingredients, is intended to be registered goods, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) includes words describing the purpose of the active ingredients, what type of information can this include that is not required by the Order?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) may include words indicating the pharmacological category or the principal intended actions of the active ingredients that are not required by the Order.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(c) allows the information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) to include words describing the purpose of the active ingredients by indicating the pharmacological category or principal intended actions, even if this information is not required by the Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, what information may still be optionally included about the active ingredients under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Even if a medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, the information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) may still optionally include words indicating the pharmacological category or principal intended actions of the active ingredients.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(ii) states that the names and quantities of active ingredients are not required on the label if the medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies. However, section 8(2)(c) still allows optional inclusion of words describing the active ingredients' pharmacological category or intended actions under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i), even if not required by the Order.

9 Information to be included on the main label (1) Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order, the information on the main label of the medicine must include: (b) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered and contains exactly 4 active ingredients, is it required for the main label to include the names of all active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(7)(c), if the medicine is registered, contains four or more active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Paragraph 9(1)(b) states that the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label. Therefore, the main label is not required to include the names of all active ingredients in this case.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is not registered and contains 5 active ingredients, is it required for the main label to include the names of all active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(c) provides an exception to the requirement in paragraph 9(1)(b) to include the names of all active ingredients on the main label. However, this exception only applies if the medicine is registered goods. Since the medicine in this case is not registered, the exception does not apply and the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label as per paragraph 9(1)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered and contains 3 active ingredients, is it required for the main label to include the names of all active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(c) provides an exception to the requirement in paragraph 9(1)(b) to include the names of all active ingredients on the main label. However, this exception only applies if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients. Since the medicine in this case contains only 3 active ingredients, the exception does not apply and the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label as per paragraph 9(1)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered, contains 6 active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, is it required for the main label to include the names of all active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(c) provides an exception to the requirement in paragraph 9(1)(b) to include the names of all active ingredients on the main label. However, this exception only applies if subsection 8(2) applies. Since subsection 8(2) does not apply in this case, the exception does not apply and the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label as per paragraph 9(1)(b), even though the medicine is registered and contains more than 4 active ingredients.

10 Qualifications and special requirements (1) Preparations for ophthalmic use In addition to the requirements of sections 8 and 9 above, if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use, the label on the container and on the primary pack or, where subsection 10(7) applies, the primary pack, must include: (e) if the medicine consists of a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use - the words ‘for eye drops’.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a small container medicine has 5 active ingredients and is an ophthalmic solid medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use, what information must be displayed on the label in a text size of at least 1.5 millimeters according to sections 10(1)(e) and 10(7)(d)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The words 'for eye drops' must be displayed in a text size of at least 1.5 millimeters.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(e) requires the words 'for eye drops' to be included on the label for a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use. Section 10(7)(d) allows the names of active ingredients to be omitted for small container medicines with 4 or more active ingredients, but still requires the information in 10(1)(e) to be displayed in a text size of at least 1.5 millimeters.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a small container ophthalmic medicine with 3 active ingredients that is not a solid for preparing eye drops. What information about the active ingredients must be displayed on the label based on sections 10(1)(e) and 10(7)(d)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of all 3 active ingredients must be displayed on the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(7)(d) requires the names of all active ingredients to be displayed for small container medicines with fewer than 4 active ingredients. Section 10(1)(e) does not apply since the medicine is not a solid for preparing eye drops, so there is no exception to the requirement to list the active ingredients.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a small container solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing multidose eye drops that has 5 active ingredients, what is the minimum text size allowed for the words 'for eye drops' on the label per sections 10(1)(e) and 10(7)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The minimum allowed text size for the words 'for eye drops' is 1.5 millimeters.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(e) requires including the words 'for eye drops' on the label for solid ophthalmic medicines for preparing multidose eye drops. Section 10(7) specifies that for small container medicines, the information required by 10(1)(e) must be displayed in a text size of at least 1.5 millimeters, regardless of the number of active ingredients.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an ophthalmic medicine in a small container is a liquid (not a solid for preparing eye drops) and has 6 active ingredients, what active ingredient information must be on the label and in what minimum text size per sections 10(1)(e) and 10(7)(d)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of the active ingredients are not required on the label for a small container liquid ophthalmic medicine with 6 active ingredients. No minimum text size for active ingredient information is specified.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(e) does not apply since the medicine is a liquid, not a solid for preparing eye drops. Section 10(7)(d) allows omitting the names of active ingredients for small container medicines with 4 or more active ingredients. With 6 active ingredients, no active ingredient information is required on the label and no minimum text size for such information is specified.

8 Information to be included on the label (4) If the information required on the label on the container is obscured by intermediate packaging, then the label on the intermediate packaging must include: (b) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of tablets individually enclosed in a blister pack, and this blister pack is further enclosed in a primary pack that has a label complying with sections 8 and 9, what information is required to be displayed on the label of the blister pack itself?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label on the blister pack is only required to display the name of the medicine, the name(s) and quantity or proportion of all active ingredients, the batch number and expiry date with their respective prefixes, and the name of the sponsor, distributor, or identifying registered trademark.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) states that if the conditions in (i), (ii) and (iii) are met, then the label on the blister pack only needs to include the information specified in (iv) through (ix), rather than fully complying with sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a medicine label is obscured by intermediate packaging, and the medicine consists of tablets in a blister pack further enclosed in a primary pack whose label complies with sections 8 and 9, is the name of the active ingredient required on both the intermediate packaging label and the blister pack label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the name(s) of all active ingredients is required on both the label of the intermediate packaging (section 8(4)(b)) and the label of the blister pack itself (section 10(9)(a)(v)).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(4) states that if the label is obscured by intermediate packaging, the intermediate packaging label must include the name(s) of active ingredients. Additionally, section 10(9)(a)(v) requires the blister pack label to include the name(s) of active ingredients, even if the primary pack label complies with sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Supposing a blister pack containing tablets is enclosed in a primary pack with a label complying with sections 8 and 9, and this primary pack is further enclosed in intermediate packaging that obscures the primary label. Is the expiry date of the medicine required to be on the label of the intermediate packaging?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the expiry date is not explicitly required on the label of the intermediate packaging. It is only required on the blister pack label (section 10(9)(a)(viii)) and implicitly on the primary pack label by virtue of complying with sections 8 and 9.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(4) lists the information required on the intermediate packaging label if it obscures the primary label, which includes the name(s) of active ingredients (8(4)(b)) but not the expiry date. The expiry date is required on the blister pack label as per section 10(9)(a)(viii).

QuestionAnswers.Question: In the case of a medicine consisting of single doses of powder individually enclosed in a dial dispenser pack, which is further enclosed in a primary pack with a label complying with sections 8 and 9, what prefix must be used before the batch number on the dial dispenser pack label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The batch number prefix must be used before the batch number on the dial dispenser pack label, as specified in section 10(9)(a)(vii).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) covers medicines with dosage units in strip, blister or dial dispenser packs. Sub-section (vii) states that the batch number on these inner pack labels must be preceded by the batch number prefix, even if the outer primary pack label complies with sections 8 and 9 which cover general labelling requirements.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (10) Subsection 9(9) does not apply: (b) where the medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2—after 30 April 2026; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (11) An active ingredient specified in Part 1 of Schedule 2, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, may be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient as specified in that Part for medicine released for supply before 1 May 2026.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine containing an active ingredient specified in Part 1 of Schedule 2 is supplied in a small container and is not labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, does subsection 9(9) apply to the medicine's main label after 30 April 2026?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, subsection 9(9) applies in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 9(10)(b), subsection 9(9) does not apply where the medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, after 30 April 2026. However, the question states that the medicine is supplied in a small container and is not labelled according to 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2. Therefore, the exception in 9(10)(b) does not apply, meaning subsection 9(9) does apply to the medicine's main label after 30 April 2026.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine containing an active ingredient specified in Part 1 of Schedule 2 is not supplied in a small container, can the active ingredient be included on the main label as per Part 1 of Schedule 2 for medicine released for supply on 1 June 2026?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the active ingredient cannot be included on the main label as per Part 1 of Schedule 2 in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(11) states that an active ingredient specified in Part 1 of Schedule 2 may be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient as specified in that Part for medicine released for supply before 1 May 2026. However, the question concerns medicine released for supply on 1 June 2026, which is after the 1 May 2026 cutoff date. Therefore, subsection 9(11) does not apply, and the active ingredient cannot be included on the main label as per Part 1 of Schedule 2.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine containing an active ingredient specified in Part 1 of Schedule 2 is supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, does subsection 9(9) apply to the medicine's main label before 1 May 2026?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, subsection 9(9) applies in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(10)(b) provides an exception where subsection 9(9) does not apply, but this exception only takes effect after 30 April 2026. The question concerns the applicability of subsection 9(9) before 1 May 2026. Since the exception in 9(10)(b) is not yet in effect during this time period, subsection 9(9) does apply to the medicine's main label, even though the medicine is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine containing an active ingredient specified in Part 1 of Schedule 2 is not supplied in a small container and is not labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, does subsection 9(9) apply to the medicine's main label after 30 April 2026?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, subsection 9(9) applies in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 9(10)(b), subsection 9(9) does not apply where the medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, after 30 April 2026. In this case, although the medicine is not supplied in a small container, it is also not labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2. Therefore, the exception in 9(10)(b) does not apply, meaning subsection 9(9) does apply to the medicine's main label after 30 April 2026.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (c) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required; or

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (b) The critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the following order: (i) Active ingredients (ii) Indications (iii) Warnings (iv) Directions for use (v) Other information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains 5 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, what information must be included on the main label according to the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine is not required to list the active ingredients or their quantities on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(c) states that if a medicine contains four or more active ingredients and section 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Since the medicine has 5 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, it falls under this exception and does not need to list the active ingredients or quantities on the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine label where section 8(2)(b) applies, in what order must the critical health information be presented?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The critical health information must be presented in the following order: (i) Active ingredients, (ii) Indications, (iii) Warnings, (iv) Directions for use, (v) Other information.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(b) clearly specifies the required order for presenting the critical health information on the label under appropriate headings: (i) Active ingredients, (ii) Indications, (iii) Warnings, (iv) Directions for use, (v) Other information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains 6 active ingredients, is intended to be registered goods, and section 8(2) applies, what information about the active ingredients must be included on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine is not required to include information about the active ingredients on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(7)(c), if a medicine contains four or more active ingredients and section 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Since the medicine has 6 active ingredients, is intended to be registered goods, and section 8(2) applies, it is exempt from including active ingredient information on the main label as per 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Under the given regulation sections, if a medicine label must present critical health information according to section 8(2)(b), which of the following would be presented first: warnings or directions for use?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: According to section 8(2)(b), warnings would be presented before directions for use in the required order of critical health information on the medicine label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(b) mandates the order in which critical health information must be presented on a medicine label. In the specified order, warnings (listed third) come before directions for use (listed fourth). Therefore, on a label complying with 8(2)(b), the warnings would be presented first, followed by the directions for use.
