contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (i) In addition to the requirements of paragraphs 11(2)(a) –11(2)(g), the following requirements apply in the circumstances specified in the following subparagraphs: (i) where the active ingredient is a herbal material, such as a dry, fresh, milled or powdered herb, as the weight of the herbal material; except where standardisation is claimed on the label, then the minimum dry or fresh weight of herbal material and also the quantity of standardised constituents(s) in the herbal material; (ii) where the active ingredient is a herbal preparation, as the dry or fresh weight of the herbal material from which the preparation was derived except: (A) where standardisation of the herbal preparation is claimed on the label, then, the minimum dry or fresh weight of herbal material from which the preparation is derived and the quantity of standardised constituents(s) in the herbal preparation; or (B) where the active ingredient is a herbal preparation that is an essential oil; (iii) where the active ingredient is an enzyme –the activity unit as specified in Column 1 of Schedule 3 to this Order in relation to a particular enzyme set out in Column 3 of that Schedule; (iv) for preparations containing Vitamin A or a derivative of Vitamin A - as the quantity or proportion of Vitamin A expressed in terms of microgram retinol equivalents; (v) for preparations containing biological organisms - as the number of organisms present per metric unit for liquids and powders and as the number of organisms present per dosage unit for other dosage forms;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains a single active ingredient that is a herbal preparation where standardisation is claimed on the label, what information must be included on the main label of the medicine, and how must it be expressed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label must include the name of the medicine and the name of the active ingredient expressed as the minimum dry or fresh weight of herbal material from which the preparation is derived and the quantity of standardised constituent(s) in the herbal preparation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(b), the name of the medicine and name of active ingredient must not be separated by any text or graphics on the main label, with some exceptions. Subparagraph 11(2)(i)(ii)(A) states that for a herbal preparation where standardisation is claimed, the quantity of the active ingredient must be expressed as the minimum dry or fresh weight of herbal material from which it's derived and the quantity of standardised constituents in the preparation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains multiple active ingredients that are all herbal materials with no standardisation claimed, what information must be on the main label, and how must the quantities of the ingredients be expressed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label must include the name of the medicine and the names of all the active ingredients, with no text or graphics separating them. The quantities of each herbal material active ingredient must be expressed as their weight.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b) requires the name of the medicine and names of active ingredients to be on the main label with no intervening text or graphics, unless the additional information is permitted by certain other provisions. For multiple herbal material active ingredients with no standardisation, none of those exceptions apply. Subparagraph 11(2)(i)(i) states that quantities of herbal material active ingredients must be expressed as their weight when no standardisation is claimed.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a non-prescription medicine containing an active ingredient that is Vitamin A, assuming the main label must also identify different formulations of the medicine, how must the name of the medicine, name of the active ingredient, and quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine and name of the active ingredient (Vitamin A) must be on the main label, and may be separated by text or graphics that identify the different formulations of the medicine. The quantity of Vitamin A must be expressed in terms of microgram retinol equivalents.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b) allows the name of the medicine and active ingredient to be separated by text or graphics that identify different formulations, as an exception to the general rule. Subparagraph 11(2)(i)(iv) specifies that for active ingredients that are Vitamin A or Vitamin A derivatives, the quantity must be expressed as micrograms of retinol equivalents.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine kit contains multiple medicines with active ingredients that are biological organisms in liquid and tablet forms, what information must be on the main label and how must the quantities of the active ingredients be expressed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label must include the names of the medicines and the names of the active ingredients. Text or graphics may separate these to identify the different component medicines. For liquid medicines, quantities of the biological organisms must be expressed as number of organisms per metric unit. For tablets, quantities must be number of organisms per dosage unit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per paragraph 9(3)(b), medicine and active ingredient names can be separated by text/graphics to identify kit components. Subparagraph 11(2)(i)(v) requires quantities of biological organisms to be expressed as number per metric unit for liquids/powders, and as number per dosage unit for other forms like tablets.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (h) for the purposes of paragraphs 11(2)(a) – 11(2)(d), for oral preparations that contain active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, it is sufficient that the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient to be included on a label be expressed as: (i) the name of the active ingredient; and (ii) the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (d) for a medicine required to be prepared before use, and: (i) where the process results in a medicine that is a liquid for ingestion: (A) as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated volume of a suitable dose of the liquid after preparation in accordance with the instructions set out on the label of the medicine; or (B) in the case where the medicine is one of a series of strengths containing the same active ingredient - as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated volume of a suitable dose of the liquid after preparation in accordance with the instructions set out on the label of the medicine with the quantity or proportion of active ingredient expressed consistently across the series in terms of the same stated dose volume; and Example: Where the dose volume is 5 mL after preparation, and there are strengths of 1 mg/mL and 5 mg/mL, these must be labelled as 5 mg in 5 mL and 25 mg in 5 mL, respectively. (ii) for any other medicines - as the weight or volume of active ingredient in a stated weight or volume of the medicine, after preparation in accordance with the instructions included in the label of the medicine;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a liquid oral mineral supplement that contains iron as the active ingredient, how should the quantity of iron be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of iron should be expressed as the name of the active ingredient (iron) and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation (e.g., Iron (as ferrous sulfate) 5 mg).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 11(2)(h), for oral preparations containing active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, the quantity of the active ingredient can be expressed as the name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation. This applies to the given scenario of a liquid oral mineral supplement containing iron.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a medicine that needs to be prepared before use, resulting in a liquid for ingestion. The medicine is part of a series of strengths containing the same active ingredient. How should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label to ensure consistency across the series?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity contained in the same stated volume of a suitable dose of the liquid after preparation, consistently across the series. For example, if the dose volume is 5 mL after preparation and there are strengths of 1 mg/mL and 5 mg/mL, they should be labeled as 5 mg in 5 mL and 25 mg in 5 mL, respectively.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(d)(i)(B) states that for a medicine required to be prepared before use, resulting in a liquid for ingestion, and is part of a series of strengths with the same active ingredient, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity contained in the same stated dose volume across the series after preparation. The provided example illustrates this requirement.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine that needs to be prepared before use but does not result in a liquid for ingestion, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For a medicine that needs to be prepared before use but does not result in a liquid for ingestion, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the weight or volume of the active ingredient in a stated weight or volume of the medicine after preparation according to the instructions on the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(d)(ii) specifies that for medicines required to be prepared before use, but not resulting in a liquid for ingestion, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the weight or volume of the active ingredient in a stated weight or volume of the medicine after preparation following the label instructions.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an oral liquid mineral supplement containing calcium, is it acceptable to express the quantity of calcium on the label as just the weight of the active ingredient per unit volume (e.g., 500 mg/5 mL)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, it is not sufficient to express the quantity of calcium as just the weight per unit volume for an oral liquid mineral supplement. The label must include both the name of the active ingredient (calcium) and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation (e.g., Calcium (as calcium carbonate) 500 mg).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 11(2)(h), for oral preparations containing active ingredients for mineral supplementation, the label must include both the name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation. Simply expressing the weight per unit volume does not meet this requirement.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (8) Individually wrapped medicines (c) Where: (i) a medicine consists of dry herbs contained in individual bags and the bag is retained around the herbs during preparation; (ii) the bags are contained in a primary pack, the label of which complies with the requirements of this Order, then the individual bag need not be labelled with the information referred to in sections 8 and 9.

8 Information to be included on the label (4) If the information required on the label on the container is obscured by intermediate packaging, then the label on the intermediate packaging must include: (a) the name of the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an individually wrapped medicine consists of dry herbs contained in individual bags that are retained during preparation and the bags are in a labeled primary pack, do the individual bags need to be labeled with the information from sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 10(8)(c), if a medicine consists of dry herbs in individual bags retained during preparation, and the bags are in a primary pack with a label complying with the Order, then the individual bags do not need to be labeled with the information from sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label is obscured by intermediate packaging, what information must be included on the label of the intermediate packaging?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(4)(a) states that if the information required on the medicine container label is obscured by intermediate packaging, then the label on the intermediate packaging must include the name of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of dry herbs in individual unlabeled bags within a labeled primary pack, and the primary pack label is then obscured by intermediate packaging, what information must be on the intermediate packaging label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(c) allows the individual herb bags to be unlabeled if they are in a primary pack with a compliant label. However, section 8(4)(a) requires that if that primary pack label is obscured by intermediate packaging, the intermediate packaging label must include the medicine name.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of dry herbs in individual bags that are discarded before preparation, and the bags are in a primary pack with a label complying with the Order, do the individual bags need to include the information from sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(c) only exempts individual herb bags from the labeling requirements in sections 8 and 9 if the bags are retained around the herbs during preparation. If the bags are discarded before preparation, this exemption does not apply and the bags must be labeled according to sections 8 and 9.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (h) for the purposes of paragraphs 11(2)(a) – 11(2)(d), for oral preparations that contain active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, it is sufficient that the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient to be included on a label be expressed as: (i) the name of the active ingredient; and (ii) the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (b) for a solid for ingestion, where there is no discrete dosage unit - as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid;

QuestionAnswers.Question: For an oral preparation containing an active ingredient intended for mineral supplementation, how should the quantity or proportion of the active ingredient be expressed on the label, assuming no other information is given?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 11(2)(h), for oral preparations that contain active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, it is sufficient that the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient to be included on a label be expressed as the name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a solid oral preparation with no discrete dosage unit, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label, assuming no exceptions apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: As the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 11(2)(b), for a solid for ingestion where there is no discrete dosage unit, the quantity of the active ingredient must be expressed as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose of the solid, subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an oral preparation contains an active ingredient for mineral supplementation and has no discrete dosage units, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(b) states that for a solid for ingestion with no discrete dosage unit, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity contained in the stated weight of a suitable dose. However, 11(2)(h) provides an exception for oral preparations containing active ingredients for mineral supplementation, allowing the quantity to be expressed as just the name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for supplementation. Since 11(2)(h) begins with "Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3)", it takes precedence over the more general requirement in 11(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: How should the quantity of an active ingredient in an oral preparation be expressed on the label if the preparation has discrete dosage units and the active ingredient is not intended for mineral supplementation, assuming no other exceptions apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient must be expressed according to one of the options in 11(2)(a) - 11(2)(d), such as the quantity per dosage unit combined with the number of units per package.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2) states that the quantity of an active ingredient must be expressed according to the options listed in 11(2)(a) - 11(2)(d), subject to the exceptions in 11(2)(i) and 11(3). 11(2)(h) provides an exception for oral preparations with active ingredients for mineral supplementation. 11(2)(b) applies to solids for ingestion with no discrete dosage units. Since this question specifies the oral preparation has discrete dosage units and the active ingredient is not for mineral supplementation, neither exception applies, so the main requirement to express the quantity according to 11(2)(a) - 11(2)(d) must be followed.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (c) The information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) may include words describing the purpose of the active ingredient(s) by indicating the pharmacological category or the principal intended actions that are not required by this Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes a pharmacological category for the active ingredient under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i), and the names of all excipients, can the names of the excipients be placed immediately below the information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(e), if information other than the critical health information or information mentioned in 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is included, such as the names of all excipients, it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b). It cannot be placed immediately below the pharmacological category information provided under 8(2)(b)(i).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes the pharmacological category of the active ingredient under 8(2)(b)(i) and sponsor contact details, can the sponsor contact details be included under the same heading as the pharmacological category?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(c) allows the pharmacological category of the active ingredient to be included under the information provided in 8(2)(b)(i). However, section 8(2)(e) specifies that sponsor contact details, being information other than critical health information or information in 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(d), must be under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading following the headings in 8(2)(b). Therefore, the sponsor details cannot be under the same heading as the pharmacological category from 8(2)(b)(i).

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a non-prescription medicine label includes storage condition requirements, information about anti-tampering package features, names of all excipients, and distributor contact details, can all of this information be placed together under a single heading labeled 'Additional Details'?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) states that if information other than critical health information or that mentioned in 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(d) is included, it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading following the 8(2)(b) headings. The listed items - storage conditions, tamper evident packaging info, excipient names, and distributor contact details - all fall into this 'other information' category according to 8(2)(e)(A-D). Therefore, they can be grouped together under a single appropriate heading like 'Additional Details' as long as this follows the 8(2)(b) headings.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label properly includes the principal intended actions of the active ingredient under 8(2)(b)(i) as permitted by 8(2)(c), and also includes the names of all excipients, is it acceptable to place the excipient names immediately below the principal intended actions?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(c) allows the principal intended actions of the active ingredient to be stated under the information required by 8(2)(b)(i). However, according to 8(2)(e), information like the names of all excipients must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b). Therefore, the excipient names cannot be placed immediately below the principal intended actions included under 8(2)(b)(i), but must be under a separate heading following the 8(2)(b) headings.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (10) Subsection 9(9) does not apply: (c) where the medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(13) and Part 2 of Schedule 2—after 30 April 2028. Note: The minimum text size for active ingredients on labels of small containers is less than 2.5 millimetres and specified elsewhere in this Order.

9 Information to be included on the main label (13) An active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, may be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient as specified in that Part for medicine released for supply before 1 May 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled according to subsection 9(13) and Part 2 of Schedule 2, will subsection 9(9) apply to it after April 30, 2028?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(10)(c) states that subsection 9(9) does not apply where the medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(13) and Part 2 of Schedule 2, after 30 April 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If an active ingredient is specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2, can it be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient as specified in that Part if the medicine is released for supply on May 15, 2028?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 9(13), an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 may be included on the main label of a medicine containing that ingredient as specified in that Part only for medicine released for supply before 1 May 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is not in a small container and its label complies with subsection 9(13) and Part 2 of Schedule 2, what is the earliest date after which subsection 9(9) will not apply to it?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(10)(c) states that subsection 9(9) does not apply after 30 April 2028 for medicines not supplied in a small container and labelled according to subsection 9(13) and Part 2 of Schedule 2. Therefore, the earliest date after which subsection 9(9) will not apply is May 1, 2028.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a medicine's active ingredient is listed in Part 2 of Schedule 2 and the medicine is released for supply on April 30, 2028, can the active ingredient be included on the main label as specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 without complying with subsection 9(9)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(13) allows an active ingredient specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 to be included on the main label as specified in that Part for medicine released before 1 May 2028. Subsection 9(10)(c) exempts medicines labelled according to subsection 9(13) and Part 2 of Schedule 2 from subsection 9(9) after 30 April 2028. Therefore, a medicine released on April 30, 2028 with an active ingredient listed in Part 2 of Schedule 2 can include the ingredient on the main label as specified without complying with subsection 9(9).

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (c) (i) the total number of active ingredients in the different formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit are to be counted; and (ii) if the same active ingredient is contained in two or more formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit, each of those active ingredients is to be counted separately, for the purposes of determining if paragraph 9(6)(b) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit, or which paragraph in subsection 9(7) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit; and

9 Information to be included on the main label (6) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods: (b) if there are four or more active ingredients in the medicine - the name of every active ingredient, together with the quantity or proportion of every active ingredient, may appear on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is intended to be listed goods and is a composite pack containing four different formulations each with a unique active ingredient, can the names and quantities of the active ingredients be listed on a side panel of the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(6)(b), if a medicine that is intended to be listed goods contains four or more active ingredients, the name and quantity of every active ingredient may appear on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label. Section 9(8)(c)(i) specifies that for a composite pack, the total number of active ingredients in the different formulations are to be counted for the purposes of determining if 9(6)(b) applies. Therefore, a composite pack with four different formulations each containing a unique active ingredient would have a total of four active ingredients, allowing the names and quantities to be listed on a side panel per 9(6)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Given a non-prescription medicine kit that is intended to be listed goods and contains two formulations of the same active ingredient along with one other unique active ingredient, is it required to list the names and quantities of the active ingredients on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(c)(ii) states that for a medicine kit, if the same active ingredient is contained in two or more formulations, each instance is to be counted separately for determining which labeling requirements in 9(6) or 9(7) apply. In this case, there are considered to be three total active ingredients - two of the same one and one unique. Since there are less than four active ingredients when counted this way, 9(6)(b) does not apply, meaning the active ingredient names and quantities cannot be listed on a side or rear panel and must appear on the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a composite pack medicine that is listed goods and has five formulations each with different active ingredients, is it acceptable to list the active ingredient information on a rear label instead of the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(c)(i) specifies that for composite packs, the total number of active ingredients across the different formulations is counted to determine labeling requirements. With five formulations each having a different active ingredient, the total active ingredient count is five. Section 9(6)(b) allows medicines that are listed goods with four or more active ingredients to have the active ingredient names and quantities listed on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label rather than the main label. So in this case, it is permitted to put the active ingredient information on the rear label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a non-prescription medicine kit that will be listed goods has three formulations - two with the same active ingredient at different strengths, and one with two different active ingredients. Can the active ingredients be listed on a side label instead of the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: To determine the labeling requirements, section 9(8)(c) specifies how to count the number of active ingredients for medicine kits. 9(8)(c)(i) says the total number across the different formulations is counted. Additionally, 9(8)(c)(ii) states that if an active ingredient is repeated in multiple formulations, each instance is counted separately. So in this case, there are four active ingredients counted for labeling purposes - the repeated one is counted twice, plus the two unique ones in the third formulation. However, 9(6)(b) only allows the active ingredients to be on a side panel/label or rear panel/label for listed medicines with four or more active ingredients. Since this has exactly four rather than more than four, 9(6)(b) does not apply and the active ingredients must be listed on the main label.

contexts: 3 Application - Therapeutic goods to which this Order applies(2) To avoid doubt, this Order will apply to the following medicines:(b) medicines exempt from the listing and registration requirements, other than those specified in section 5 of this Order.

5 Exemptions – Medicines to which this Order does not apply (2) The requirements of this Order do not apply to a transparent covering that encloses or wraps the container or primary pack containing a medicine and where the information that is required to be set out on the label of the container or the primary pack is clearly visible through that transparent covering.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is exempt from listing and registration requirements, and is not enclosed in a transparent covering that allows the required label information to be clearly visible, does this Order apply to the labelling requirements for that medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, this Order applies.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(2)(b) states that this Order applies to medicines exempt from listing and registration requirements, other than those specified in section 5. Section 5(2) exempts medicines from this Order only if they are enclosed in a transparent covering through which the required label information is clearly visible. Since the medicine in question is exempt but not enclosed in a qualifying transparent covering, the Order applies to its labelling requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a non-prescription medicine that is exempt from listing and registration requirements. It is enclosed in a transparent covering, but the required label information on the container is not clearly visible through the covering. Does this Order apply to the labelling of this medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, this Order applies.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 3(2)(b), this Order applies to medicines exempt from listing and registration requirements, unless they are specified in section 5. Section 5(2) only exempts a medicine from this Order if it is in a transparent covering AND the required label information is clearly visible through that covering. Since the label is not clearly visible in this case, the medicine is not exempt under 5(2), so the Order applies per 3(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a non-prescription medicine is not exempt from listing and registration requirements, and it is not enclosed in any transparent covering. Assuming no other exemptions in section 5 apply, is the labelling of this medicine subject to the requirements of this Order?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, this Order applies.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(2) states that this Order applies to non-prescription medicines, which includes both exempt and non-exempt medicines, unless specified in section 5. The only potentially relevant exemption in section 5 is in 5(2), which exempts medicines enclosed in a transparent covering through which the required label information is visible. Since this medicine is not exempt and has no transparent covering, no section 5 exemptions apply, so it is subject to this Order under the broad scope of section 3(2).

QuestionAnswers.Question: A non-prescription medicine is wrapped in a transparent covering. The container inside has a label with the required information, which can be clearly seen through the transparent outer wrap. Is the labelling of this medicine subject to the requirements of this Order?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, this Order does not apply.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(2)(b) states that this Order applies to non-prescription medicines that are exempt from listing and registration, other than those specified in section 5. Section 5(2) specifically exempts medicines from this Order if they are enclosed in a transparent covering through which the required label information on the container or primary pack is clearly visible. Since this medicine meets the criteria in 5(2), it is exempt from the requirements of this Order.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (d) The information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(iii) may include safety related information not required by this Order (such as allergen advice, caution, additional warning or advisory statements).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Under section 8(2)(d), can safety-related information not required by the Order, such as allergen advice, caution statements, or additional warnings, be included under the paragraph 8(2)(b)(iii) heading? Assume all information will be placed under the appropriate headings per 8(2)(e).
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(d) explicitly allows safety related information not required by the Order, such as allergen advice, caution statements, additional warnings or advisory statements, to be included under the paragraph 8(2)(b)(iii) heading. Section 8(2)(e) requires any additional non-critical information to be placed under appropriate separate headings following the headings in 8(2)(b), so the assumption that all information will be correctly placed is satisfied.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a non-prescription medicine label includes the names of all excipients under an 'Other ingredients' heading immediately following the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b), and no other non-critical information is included, does this comply with section 8(2)(e)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) allows the names of all excipients to be placed under an appropriate separate heading immediately following the headings in 8(2)(b). An 'Other ingredients' heading for the excipients would satisfy this requirement. Since no other non-critical information is included, the label complies with the restriction in 8(2)(e) on what additional information may be included.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a label includes allergen advice under 8(2)(d) and lists excipient names under a separate heading per 8(2)(e), is the label allowed to also include the sponsor contact details under another heading below the excipient names?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(d) allows allergen advice to be included under the 8(2)(b)(iii) heading. Section 8(2)(e) then permits excipient names to be listed under an appropriate separate heading after the 8(2)(b) headings. Finally, 8(2)(e) also allows sponsor contact details to be included under yet another heading following the excipient names. Therefore, the label described satisfies all the requirements of 8(2)(d) and 8(2)(e).

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a label that includes storage condition requirements under an 'Other information' heading per 8(2)(e), can that same 'Other information' heading also contain both the excipient names and distributor contact details?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) allows requirements relating to storage conditions to be placed under an 'Other information' heading. However, it specifies that excipient names and distributor contact details must be under separate appropriate headings, not combined with storage conditions or each other under the same 'Other information' heading. Excipient names and distributor contacts must each have their own distinct heading according to 8(2)(e).

contexts: 4 Transition arrangements (3) Notwithstanding (1) and (2), medicines imported into or manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date must comply with TGO 69 (2017) if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017).
4 Transition arrangements (2) On and from 1 September 2020, each medicine to which this Order applies must comply with the requirements specified in this Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was imported into Australia on 1 August 2020 and supplied by a sponsor on 1 October 2020, which version of TGO must it comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to clause 4(2), medicines must comply with the requirements of this Order from 1 September 2020 onwards. However, clause 4(3) provides an exception for medicines imported before 1 September 2020 but supplied by someone other than the sponsor after that date. In this case, since the medicine was imported before 1 September 2020 and supplied by the sponsor after that date, it must comply with TGO 69 (2017) as per clause 4(3).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was manufactured in Australia on 1 July 2020 and supplied by a distributor on 1 November 2020, which version of TGO must it comply with at the time of release for supply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to clause 4(2), medicines must comply with the requirements of this Order from 1 September 2020 onwards. However, clause 4(3) provides an exception for medicines manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by someone other than the sponsor after that date, if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017). Since the medicine was manufactured before 1 September 2020 and supplied by a distributor (not the sponsor) after that date, it must comply with TGO 69 (2017) at the time of release for supply as per clause 4(3).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was imported into Australia on 1 October 2020 and supplied by the sponsor on 1 November 2020, which version of TGO must it comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The version specified in this Order
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to clause 4(2), medicines must comply with the requirements specified in this Order from 1 September 2020 onwards. Clause 4(3) provides an exception only for medicines imported or manufactured before 1 September 2020. Since the medicine was imported on 1 October 2020, which is after 1 September 2020, it does not qualify for the exception in clause 4(3). Therefore, it must comply with the version of TGO specified in this Order as per clause 4(2).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was manufactured in Australia on 1 August 2020 and supplied by the sponsor on 1 December 2020, which version of TGO must it comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The version specified in this Order
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to clause 4(2), medicines must comply with the requirements specified in this Order from 1 September 2020 onwards. Clause 4(3) provides an exception for medicines manufactured before 1 September 2020, but only if they are supplied by someone other than the sponsor after that date. Since the medicine was manufactured before 1 September 2020 but supplied by the sponsor after that date, it does not qualify for the exception in clause 4(3). Therefore, it must comply with the version of TGO specified in this Order as per clause 4(2).

contexts: 3 Application - Therapeutic goods to which this Order applies(1) Subject to sections 4 and 5, this Order applies to medicines supplied or for supply in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91 – Standard for labels of prescription and related medicines.

5 Exemptions – Medicines to which this Order does not apply (2) The requirements of this Order do not apply to a transparent covering that encloses or wraps the container or primary pack containing a medicine and where the information that is required to be set out on the label of the container or the primary pack is clearly visible through that transparent covering.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in Australia and is not a prescription medicine, does this Order apply to the labelling requirements for that medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(1) states that this Order applies to medicines supplied in Australia, other than those specified under Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91 which covers prescription medicines. Therefore, if a medicine is supplied in Australia and is not a prescription medicine, this Order applies to its labelling requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a medicine to which this Order applies is enclosed in a transparent covering, and the required label information is clearly visible through the covering, do the labelling requirements of this Order still apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 5(2) provides an exemption from the requirements of this Order for medicines enclosed in a transparent covering, provided that the required label information on the container or primary pack is clearly visible through the covering.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is an over-the-counter product supplied in Australia, enclosed in a transparent covering with the label visible, do the labelling requirements of this Order apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Based on sections 3(1) and 5(2), this Order applies to non-prescription medicines supplied in Australia, but provides an exemption if the medicine is in a transparent covering through which the required label information is clearly visible. As an over-the-counter medicine is non-prescription, and the label is visible through the covering, the labelling requirements of this Order do not apply in this scenario.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a complementary medicine supplied in Australia without a prescription, not enclosed in any covering, do the labelling requirements of this Order apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(1) makes this Order applicable to non-prescription medicines supplied in Australia. A complementary medicine supplied without a prescription falls into this category. Since section 5(2) only provides an exemption for medicines in a transparent covering with a visible label, which does not apply here as there is no covering, the labelling requirements of this Order are applicable to the complementary medicine in this scenario.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (h) for the purposes of paragraphs 11(2)(a) – 11(2)(d), for oral preparations that contain active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, it is sufficient that the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient to be included on a label be expressed as: (i) the name of the active ingredient; and (ii) the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (c) subject to paragraph (d) below, if the medicine is a liquid for ingestion: (i) as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated volume of a suitable dose of the liquid; or (ii) in the case where the liquid for ingestion is one of a series of strengths containing the same active ingredient – as the quantity of the active ingredient contained in the stated volume of a suitable dose of the liquid with the quantity or proportion of active ingredient expressed consistently across the series in terms of the same stated dose volume. Example: Where the dose volume is 5 mL, and there are strengths of 1 mg/mL and 5 mg/mL, these must be labelled as 5 mg in 5 mL and 25 mg in 5 mL, respectively.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For an oral mineral supplement liquid with active ingredient magnesium at a strength of 2 mg/mL, how should the quantity of magnesium be expressed on the label if the recommended dose is 10 mL? Assume no other information is required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 20 mg in 10 mL
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 11(2)(h), for oral preparations containing active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, the quantity of the active ingredient can be expressed as the name of the ingredient and the quantity of the element. 11(2)(c)(i) states that for liquid medicines, the quantity should be expressed as the amount of active ingredient in a stated dose volume. With a strength of 2 mg/mL magnesium and a 10 mL dose, the label should state the quantity as 20 mg magnesium in 10 mL.

QuestionAnswers.Question: How should the quantity of magnesium be expressed on the labels of oral liquid mineral supplements that come in strengths of 1 mg/mL, 2 mg/mL and 4 mg/mL if the dose volume is 5 mL? Assume no other information is required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 5 mg in 5 mL, 10 mg in 5 mL, 20 mg in 5 mL
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(h) allows oral mineral supplements to express the quantity as the name and amount of the mineral element. 11(2)(c)(ii) requires that for a series of strengths of the same active ingredient, the quantity must be expressed consistently in terms of the same dose volume across the series. With a 5 mL dose volume and strengths of 1, 2 and 4 mg/mL of magnesium, the labels should state the quantities as 5 mg in 5 mL, 10 mg in 5 mL and 20 mg in 5 mL respectively.

QuestionAnswers.Question: A company makes two oral magnesium supplement liquids, one at a strength of 2 mg/mL and one at 10 mg/mL. The dose is 10 mL for the 2 mg/mL product and 5 mL for the 10 mg/mL product. How should the quantity of magnesium be expressed on each label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 20 mg in 10 mL for the 2 mg/mL product, 50 mg in 5 mL for the 10 mg/mL product
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(h) permits oral mineral supplements to express the quantity as the name and amount of the mineral element. 11(2)(c)(i) requires liquids to express the quantity as the amount in a stated dose volume. These are two different products with different strengths and dose volumes, so 11(2)(c)(ii) regarding consistent expression across a series does not apply. Therefore, the 2 mg/mL product label should state 20 mg magnesium in 10 mL, and the 10 mg/mL product label should state 50 mg magnesium in 5 mL.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For an oral liquid vitamin D supplement with a strength of 400 IU/mL, how should the quantity of vitamin D be expressed on the label if the dose is 1 mL? Assume no other information is required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 400 IU in 1 mL
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 11(2)(h) does not apply since vitamin D is not a mineral element. Therefore, 11(2)(c)(i) applies, requiring the quantity to be expressed as the amount of active ingredient (vitamin D) in a stated dose volume. With a strength of 400 IU/mL and a 1 mL dose, the label should state the quantity as 400 IU vitamin D in 1 mL.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (h) for the purposes of paragraphs 11(2)(a) – 11(2)(d), for oral preparations that contain active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, it is sufficient that the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient to be included on a label be expressed as: (i) the name of the active ingredient; and (ii) the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient intended for mineral supplementation and is an oral preparation, what information must be included on the label to express the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 11(2)(h), for oral preparations that contain active ingredients intended for mineral supplementation, the quantity or proportion of that active ingredient can be expressed as the name of the active ingredient and the name and quantity of the element intended for mineral supplementation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label includes the name of the medicine and the names of active ingredients, can any text or graphics be placed between the medicine name and the active ingredient names?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, text or graphics cannot be placed between the medicine name and active ingredient names, with a few specific exceptions.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b) states that the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) must not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by paragraph 11(2)(h), subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A), or subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an oral preparation contains an active ingredient for mineral supplementation, and the label expresses this using the format specified in paragraph 11(2)(h), can any text or graphics be placed between the medicine name and this mineral supplementation information on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, text or graphics can be placed between the medicine name and the mineral supplementation information in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(3)(b)(i)(A) provides an exception allowing the mineral supplementation information required by paragraph 11(2)(h) to be separated from the medicine name by text or graphics on the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an oral preparation medicine label includes the active ingredient name and element name and quantity for mineral supplementation per paragraph 11(2)(h), is this sufficient to meet the general requirement to express the quantity or proportion of active ingredients on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, for an oral preparation containing an active ingredient for mineral supplementation, expressing the information in the format specified by paragraph 11(2)(h) is sufficient to meet the general label requirements for expressing quantity or proportion of active ingredients, subject to the exceptions in paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The opening text of paragraph 11(2) states that subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3), expressing the mineral supplementation information as specified in 11(2)(h) is sufficient to meet the active ingredient quantity/proportion labeling requirement for applicable oral preparations.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (c) The information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) may include words describing the purpose of the active ingredient(s) by indicating the pharmacological category or the principal intended actions that are not required by this Order.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (b) The critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the following order: (i) Active ingredients (ii) Indications (iii) Warnings (iv) Directions for use (v) Other information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription drug label includes the pharmacological category or principal intended actions of the active ingredients under the 'Active ingredients' heading, would this be in compliance with the labeling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(b), the critical health information on the label must include the active ingredients, and this information should be presented under the 'Active ingredients' heading. Section 8(2)(c) further clarifies that the information provided under 8(2)(b)(i) (i.e., active ingredients) may include words describing the purpose of the active ingredients by indicating the pharmacological category or principal intended actions. Therefore, including the pharmacological category or principal intended actions under the 'Active ingredients' heading would be in compliance with the labeling requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription drug label presents the critical health information in the following order: Warnings, Active ingredients, Indications, Directions for use, Other information. Would this be compliant with the labeling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(b), the critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the following specific order: (i) Active ingredients, (ii) Indications, (iii) Warnings, (iv) Directions for use, (v) Other information. The order presented in the question (Warnings, Active ingredients, Indications, Directions for use, Other information) does not follow the required order specified in 8(2)(b). Therefore, this labeling would not be compliant with the requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription drug label includes the pharmacological category of the active ingredients, but this information is presented under the 'Indications' heading. Would this be compliant with the labeling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(c), the information about the pharmacological category or principal intended actions of the active ingredients may be included under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i), which refers to the 'Active ingredients' heading. Section 8(2)(b) requires the critical health information to be presented under appropriate headings, with 'Active ingredients' and 'Indications' as separate headings. Therefore, including the pharmacological category under the 'Indications' heading instead of the 'Active ingredients' heading would not be compliant with the labeling requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription drug label includes all the required critical health information under appropriate headings, but the order of the headings is: Active ingredients, Warnings, Indications, Other information, Directions for use. Would this be compliant with the labeling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(b), the critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the following specific order: (i) Active ingredients, (ii) Indications, (iii) Warnings, (iv) Directions for use, (v) Other information. Although the label includes all the required information under appropriate headings, the order of the headings (Active ingredients, Warnings, Indications, Other information, Directions for use) does not match the order specified in 8(2)(b). Therefore, this labeling would not be compliant with the requirements.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "critical health information" means information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) of this Order, that is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (j) where: (i) a substance or substance within the group of substances referred to in Column 1 of Schedule 1 to this Order is present in the medicine; (ii) the circumstances as set out in Column 2 of Schedule 1 exist in relation to such a substance or no circumstances are set out in Column 2; and (iii) the medicine is intended to be administered via any one or more of the route(s) of administration referred to in Column 3 of Schedule 1, then: (iv) a statement: (A) indicating that the medicine contains the substance expressed using the Name stated in Column 4 of Schedule 1; and (B) where any of the circumstances and requirements set out in Column 2 of Schedule 1 exist in relation to the substance – a statement of the kind referred to as a ‘requirement’ in that Column (if any); and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains the substance Astemizole at 0.1% or less per dosage unit and is intended for oral administration, what information must be included on the label according to paragraphs 8(1)(j)(iv)(A) and 8(1)(j)(iv)(B)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must state that the medicine contains Astemizole.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 8(1)(j)(iv)(A), the label must include a statement indicating that the medicine contains the substance Astemizole. Since the medicine contains 0.1% or less Astemizole per dosage unit and is intended for oral administration, it matches the criteria in Schedule 1 referenced in 8(1)(j)(i)-(iii). However, no additional statement is required per 8(1)(j)(iv)(B) since Column 2 of Schedule 1 does not specify any other circumstances or requirements for Astemizole.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is intended for rectal administration and contains Bisacodyl at more than 5 mg per dosage unit, what information must be included on the label per paragraphs 8(1)(j)(iv)(A) and 8(1)(j)(iv)(B)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must state that the medicine contains Bisacodyl and include the statement 'not for use in children under 12 years'.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per paragraph 8(1)(j)(iv)(A), the label must state the medicine contains Bisacodyl, since it matches the criteria in Schedule 1 referenced in 8(1)(j)(i)-(iii) for Bisacodyl administered rectally at over 5 mg per dose. Additionally, 8(1)(j)(iv)(B) requires including the statement 'not for use in children under 12 years', because Column 2 of Schedule 1 specifies this as a requirement for Bisacodyl under the given circumstances.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine contains Potassium salts and is intended for oral administration, which pieces of information in paragraph 8(1) are considered 'critical health information' that must be included on the label per paragraph 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The warning statement about Potassium content required by paragraph 8(1)(j)(iv)(B) is considered critical health information that must be on the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 6 defines 'critical health information' as including the information required under paragraph 8(1)(j). For a medicine containing Potassium salts intended for oral use, paragraph 8(1)(j)(iv)(B) requires the label to include the warning statement specified in Column 2 of Schedule 1. Therefore, this Potassium warning is critical health information per the definition in paragraph 6.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an oral non-prescription medicine contains multiple substances listed in Schedule 1, including Salicylic acid at 12% w/w and Zinc compounds at an equivalent of 25 mg zinc per dosage unit, what substance information must be stated on the label per paragraphs 8(1)(j)(iv)(A) and 8(1)(j)(iv)(B)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must state that the medicine contains Salicylic acid and Zinc, and include the warnings 'Not suitable for use in children' for the Salicylic acid and 'WARNING - Contains zinc which may be dangerous if taken in large amounts or for a long period' for the Zinc compounds.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per 8(1)(j)(iv)(A), the label must state the medicine contains both Salicylic acid and Zinc, since both match their respective Schedule 1 criteria referenced in 8(1)(j)(i)-(iii). For Salicylic acid, 8(1)(j)(iv)(B) requires the 'Not suitable for use in children' warning from Column 2 of Schedule 1. Similarly, for Zinc compounds, 8(1)(j)(iv)(B) mandates the zinc warning statement specified in Column 2. So the label must include the substance names and both warning statements to fully comply with paragraphs 8(1)(j)(iv)(A) and (B).

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (10) Subsection 9(9) does not apply: (b) where the medicine is not supplied in a small container and is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2—after 30 April 2026; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (9) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and the name of an active ingredient included in the medicine comprises an ingredient name specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, then the names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is registered goods and contains an active ingredient with a name specified in Schedule 2, and it is supplied in a container that is not small, under what conditions can the name and quantity/proportion of the active ingredient be displayed in text less than 2.5 millimeters on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name and quantity/proportion of the active ingredient can be displayed in text less than 2.5 millimeters if the medicine is labelled in accordance with subsection 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, and this occurs after 30 April 2026.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(9) requires the names and quantities/proportions of active ingredients to be in at least 2.5mm text on the main label for registered medicines containing Schedule 2 ingredients. However, 9(10)(b) provides an exception to 9(9) for medicines not in small containers that are labelled per 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, after 30 April 2026.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a registered non-prescription medicine contains an active ingredient listed in Schedule 2 and is packaged in a small container, is it ever permitted to display the active ingredient name and quantity in text smaller than 2.5 millimeters on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, it is never permitted to display the active ingredient name and quantity in text smaller than 2.5 millimeters on the main label in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(9) mandates that for registered medicines with Schedule 2 ingredients, the active ingredient names and quantities must be in minimum 2.5mm text on the main label. The exception in 9(10)(b) allowing smaller text only applies to medicines not in small containers. Since this medicine is in a small container, the minimum 2.5mm text size requirement in 9(9) always applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a registered non-prescription medicine contains multiple active ingredients, one of which has a name listed in Schedule 2, and the medicine is not packaged in a small container, what is the earliest date the main label can display the names and quantities of the active ingredients in text smaller than 2.5 millimeters if it complies with the labelling requirements in 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 1 May 2026 is the earliest date the main label can display the active ingredient names and quantities in text smaller than 2.5 millimeters in this scenario.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(9) requires at least 2.5mm text for active ingredient details on registered medicines with a Schedule 2 ingredient. However, 9(10)(b) allows an exception for medicines not in small containers that are labelled according to 9(11) and Part 1 of Schedule 2, but only after 30 April 2026. So 1 May 2026 is the earliest date the smaller text is permitted.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is not registered goods but it contains an active ingredient that has a name specified in Schedule 2, and the medicine is not packaged in a small container, do the requirements in subsections 9(9) and 9(10) regarding minimum text size for displaying the active ingredient names and quantities on the main label apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the minimum text size requirements in subsections 9(9) and 9(10) do not apply in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(9) specifies that the minimum 2.5mm text size for active ingredient names and quantities only applies if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods. Since this medicine is stated to not be registered goods, 9(9) does not apply, and therefore the exception in 9(10) is also not applicable, even though the medicine is not in a small container.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (b) If, in relation to a medicine referred to in (a) there are: (i) four or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods; or (ii) two or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods, then, in relation to compliance of the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the following information is displayed: (iii) the name of the medicine; and (iv) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and (v) the expiry date of the medicine preceded by the expiry date prefix; and (vi) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (n) a statement of the purpose or purposes for which it is intended that the medicine be used, except where: (i) the medicine is: (A) supplied solely to a complementary healthcare practitioner for supply to a person after affixing by the practitioner of an instruction label on the medicine following a consultation with that person; and (B) the label of the medicine includes the words ‘For Practitioner Dispensing Only’; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied solely to a complementary healthcare practitioner for supply to a person after affixing an instruction label on the medicine following a consultation, and the medicine label includes 'For Practitioner Dispensing Only', does the label need to include a statement of the purpose for which the medicine is intended to be used according to sections 8(1)(n) and 10(9)(b)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(1)(n), the label does not need to include a statement of purpose if the medicine is supplied solely to a complementary healthcare practitioner for dispensing after consultation, and the label includes 'For Practitioner Dispensing Only'. Section 10(9)(b) does not override this exception.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered medicine with 4 active ingredients, packaged in a blister pack, assuming sections 8 and 9 are not fully complied with on the blister pack label, what information must be displayed on the blister pack label to be sufficient for compliance per section 10(9)(b)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine, batch number preceded by the batch number prefix, expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix, and name of the sponsor/distributor or registered trademark if it identifies them.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b) states that for a registered medicine with 4 or more active ingredients in a blister pack, if the label does not fully comply with sections 8 and 9, it is sufficient to display the medicine name, batch number with prefix, expiry date with prefix, and sponsor/distributor name or identifying trademark.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a listed medicine has 3 active ingredients and is packaged in strip packs, does section 10(9)(b) specify reduced labeling requirements for the strip pack labels if sections 8 and 9 are not fully met?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(ii) specifies reduced labeling requirements only for listed medicines with 2 or more active ingredients. Since this is a listed medicine with 3 active ingredients, it does not meet the criteria in 10(9)(b) for the labeling exception. Full compliance with sections 8 and 9 would be required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a registered medicine with 5 active ingredients is packaged in dial dispenser packs and the dial pack labels do not state the purpose for which the medicine is intended to be used, can section 10(9)(b) be applied to allow reduced labeling requirements and consider the labels compliant?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The medicine has more than 4 active ingredients and is registered, so it meets the criteria in section 10(9)(b)(i). This allows the reduced labeling on the dial pack specified in 10(9)(b)(iii)-(vi) to be considered sufficient for compliance with sections 8 and 9. Section 8(1)(n) normally requires the label to state the purpose, but 10(9)(b) provides an exception.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (d) the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately in relation to each formulation of medicine in the composite pack or medicine kit.

9 Information to be included on the main label (6) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods: (b) if there are four or more active ingredients in the medicine - the name of every active ingredient, together with the quantity or proportion of every active ingredient, may appear on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is listed goods and contains 5 active ingredients, can the name and quantity of every active ingredient appear on the main label? If not, where must this information appear?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the name and quantity of every active ingredient cannot appear on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 9(6)(b), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods and has four or more active ingredients, the name and quantity or proportion of every active ingredient may appear on a side panel, side label, rear panel or rear label, rather than the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine that is listed goods and comes in a composite pack with multiple formulations, is the name and quantity of active ingredients required to be provided separately for each formulation, or can it be provided collectively? Assume there are 5 active ingredients per formulation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name and quantity of active ingredients must be provided separately for each formulation in the composite pack.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(8)(d) states that where a listed medicine comes in a composite pack, the information required under 9(6)(b) (name and quantity of 4 or more active ingredients appearing on side/rear panel/label rather than main label) must be provided separately in relation to each formulation of medicine in the composite pack.

QuestionAnswers.Question: A listed medicine kit contains 3 different medicine formulations, each with 6 active ingredients. Assuming the name and quantity of active ingredients is not on the main label, can this information be provided collectively for all formulations on a single side panel of the kit? Why or why not?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the name and quantity of the 6 active ingredients for each of the 3 formulations cannot be provided collectively on a single side panel of the medicine kit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(6)(b) allows the name and quantity of 4 or more active ingredients in a listed medicine to appear on a side/rear panel or label rather than the main label. However, 9(8)(d) clarifies that for a medicine kit, this information must be provided separately for each formulation in the kit. Therefore, the active ingredient details need to be listed separately for the 3 different formulations, not collectively.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a listed medicine containing 7 active ingredients, if the name and quantity of each ingredient is included on a side label, can any part of this information also appear on the main label? Justify your answer.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, some or all of the name and quantity information for the 7 active ingredients can appear on the main label in addition to the side label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(6)(b) states that for a listed medicine with 4 or more active ingredients, the name and quantity of every active ingredient may appear on a side/rear panel or label. The use of "may" indicates this location is optional, not mandatory. Therefore, this information can appear on the main label as well as the side label. 9(6)(b) does not prohibit any of these details from the main label.
