contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (c) where paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply- the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine

11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (b) where all active ingredients of the medicine are homoeopathic preparations and are all included in the medicine in the same proportion - as ‘Contains equal parts of ...’ followed by the name of each active ingredient; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic medicine contains active ingredients X and Y in equal proportion, what information must be included on the label of the container and primary pack of this medicine regarding the quantity or proportion of the active ingredients, according to the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the text 'Contains equal parts of ...' followed by the names of the active ingredients X and Y.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(3)(b) states that if all active ingredients of a homoeopathic medicine are included in the same proportion, the label must include the text 'Contains equal parts of ...' followed by the name of each active ingredient. Since the question assumes active ingredients X and Y are in equal proportion, this clause applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a homoeopathic medicine where the active ingredients are not all included in the same proportion, and sections 11(3)(a) and 11(3)(b) do not apply. According to the given regulation, what quantity or proportion information must be provided on the label of the container and primary pack of this medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the quantity of the homoeopathic preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(3)(c) states that where paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply, the label on the container and primary pack of a homoeopathic medicine must include the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or one gram of the medicine. The question assumes sections 11(3)(a) and 11(3)(b) do not apply, so section 11(3)(c) is the relevant requirement here.

QuestionAnswers.Question: A homoeopathic medicine contains three active ingredients: A, B, and C. Ingredients A and B are in equal proportion, but ingredient C is in a different proportion. Assuming sections 11(3)(a) and 11(3)(b) do not apply, what quantity or proportion information must be included on the label as per the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the quantity of the homoeopathic preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Although ingredients A and B are in equal proportion, ingredient C is in a different proportion. Therefore, not all active ingredients are included in the same proportion, so section 11(3)(b) does not apply. The question also assumes section 11(3)(a) does not apply. In this case, section 11(3)(c) requires that the label include the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or one gram of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a homoeopathic medicine where sections 11(3)(a), 11(3)(b), and 11(3)(c) all do not apply, what quantity or proportion information about the active ingredients, if any, is required to be on the label of the container and primary pack based solely on the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The given regulation sections do not specify any labelling requirements for quantity or proportion of active ingredients in a homoeopathic medicine if sections 11(3)(a), 11(3)(b), and 11(3)(c) all do not apply.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Sections 11(3)(a), 11(3)(b), and 11(3)(c) cover different scenarios for expressing the quantity or proportion of active ingredients on the label of a homoeopathic medicine. However, these are the only relevant provisions in the given regulation sections. If none of these three sections apply, the given regulation excerpts do not mandate any other requirements for indicating quantity or proportion of active ingredients on the label.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;

11 How information is to be expressed (5) Inclusion of common names of vitamins Where a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, then the word ‘vitamin’, or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label of the medicine either: (b) on a separate line of text - immediately below the related name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin and the quantity of that active ingredient.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, can the common name of that vitamin appear on the main label immediately below the related name and quantity of the active ingredient, on a separate line of text?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 11(5)(b), where a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, the word 'vitamin' or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label immediately below the related name of the active ingredient and the quantity of that active ingredient, on a separate line of text.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, can any text or graphics separate the name of the medicine from the name of that active ingredient on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, with some exceptions
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(b), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must not be separated by any text or graphics, with some specific exceptions listed in subparagraphs 9(3)(b)(i) and (ii). One of those exceptions, as per 9(3)(b)(i)(C), is the inclusion of the common name of a vitamin active ingredient as permitted by subsection 11(5).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, can the common name of that vitamin be included on the main label without the word 'vitamin' or a suitable abbreviation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 11(5) states that where a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, the word 'vitamin', or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label of the medicine. This implies that the common name of the vitamin cannot be included without the word 'vitamin' or a suitable abbreviation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, is it required to include the common name of that vitamin on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The wording in subsection 11(5) uses 'may' when referring to the inclusion of the word 'vitamin' together with the common name of that vitamin on the main label. This indicates that it is permitted but not required to include this information for active ingredients that are vitamins.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a small container of medicine has an expiry date of January 2025 and active ingredients are listed on the main label, what information must be included on the main label and how should it be formatted?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label must include the name of the medicine, name(s) of active ingredient(s), and the expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix. The name of the medicine and active ingredient(s) must not be separated by any text or graphics, with some exceptions as outlined in 9(3)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(7)(j) requires the expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix on small containers. Section 9(3)(b) specifies that the name of the medicine and active ingredient(s) must not be separated by text or graphics on the main label, with some exceptions.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is packaged in a small container and has multiple active ingredients, what information is required on the main label and how must the expiry date be formatted?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label must include the name of the medicine, the names of all active ingredients, and the expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix. The name of the medicine and active ingredients must not be separated by any text or graphics, with some exceptions as outlined in 9(3)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(7)(j) requires the expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix on small containers. Section 9(3)(b) specifies that the name of the medicine and names of active ingredients must not be separated by text or graphics on the main label, with some exceptions.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine in a small container with an expiry date of June 2023, assuming the active ingredients are required to be listed on the main label, how should this information be presented to comply with the regulations?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The main label must include the expiry date 'June 2023' preceded by the expiry date prefix, as well as the name of the medicine and names of the active ingredients. The medicine name and active ingredients must not be separated by any text or graphics, except as permitted by the exceptions in 9(3)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 10(7)(j) requires the expiry date format with prefix for small containers. 9(3)(b) specifies the medicine name and active ingredients must not be separated on the main label, with some allowed exceptions.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a small container of medicine lists the active ingredients on the main label, what is the required format for displaying the expiry date, and how must the active ingredients be presented in relation to the medicine name?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The expiry date on the small container must be preceded by the expiry date prefix. The active ingredients and medicine name must be on the main label and cannot be separated by any text or graphics, except where permitted by the specific exceptions outlined in 9(3)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The expiry date format for small containers is specified in 10(7)(j). The requirement for active ingredients and medicine name to be unseparated on the main label, with limited exceptions, is stated in 9(3)(b).

contexts: 3 Application - Therapeutic goods to which this Order applies(1) Subject to sections 4 and 5, this Order applies to medicines supplied or for supply in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91 – Standard for labels of prescription and related medicines.

4 Transition arrangements (3) Notwithstanding (1) and (2), medicines imported into or manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date must comply with TGO 69 (2017) if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was supplied in Australia on 1 October 2020 by a sponsor, and it did not meet the requirements of section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91, which Order would the medicine's label need to comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine's label would need to comply with this Order (the Standard for labels of non-prescription medicines).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(1) states that this Order applies to medicines supplied in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91. Since the medicine was supplied on 1 October 2020 (after the 1 September 2020 transition date mentioned in section 4) by a sponsor and did not meet the requirements of section 3 of TGO No. 91, its label must comply with this Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was manufactured in Australia on 1 August 2020, imported into Australia before 1 September 2020, and supplied by a person other than the sponsor after 1 September 2020, which Order would the medicine's label need to comply with if it complied with TGO 69 (2017) at the time of release for supply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine's label would need to comply with TGO 69 (2017).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 4(3) states that medicines imported into or manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date must comply with TGO 69 (2017) if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017). Since the medicine was manufactured on 1 August 2020 (before 1 September 2020), imported before 1 September 2020, and complied with TGO 69 (2017) at the time of release for supply, its label must comply with TGO 69 (2017) even though it was supplied after 1 September 2020.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was supplied in Australia on 1 October 2020 by a sponsor and met the requirements of section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91, which Order would the medicine's label need to comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine's label would not need to comply with this Order (the Standard for labels of non-prescription medicines).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(1) states that this Order applies to medicines supplied in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91. Since the medicine met the requirements of section 3 of TGO No. 91, it is exempt from this Order per section 3(1).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was manufactured in Australia on 1 October 2020, supplied by the sponsor on the same date, and did not meet the requirements of section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91, which Order would the medicine's label need to comply with?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine's label would need to comply with this Order (the Standard for labels of non-prescription medicines).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 3(1) states that this Order applies to medicines supplied in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91. Section 4(3) provides a transition arrangement only for medicines manufactured before 1 September 2020 and supplied by someone other than the sponsor after that date. Since the medicine was manufactured on 1 October 2020 (after 1 September 2020), supplied by the sponsor, and did not meet the requirements of section 3 of TGO No. 91, its label must comply with this Order.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (8) Individually wrapped medicines (b) If: (i) the medicine consists only of pastilles or lozenges; and (ii) each dosage unit is enclosed in an unsealed individual wrapper; and (iii) each dosage unit is, after being so wrapped, enclosed in a primary pack that complies with sections 8 and 9, then, in relation to compliance of the label for each individual wrapper with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the name of the medicine is displayed.

9 Information to be included on the main label (9) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and the name of an active ingredient included in the medicine comprises an ingredient name specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, then the names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.
10 Qualifications and special requirements (5) Sunscreen preparations If: (a) the medicine is a sunscreen preparation; and

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (l) directions for use of the medicine except where: (i) the dose of the medicine is usually determined for each individual patient by a health professional authorised under a law of a State or Territory to determine the dose; or (ii) there is insufficient space on the label of either the container or the primary pack, or both, to include directions for use, and: (A) those directions for use are set out in a package insert provided in the primary pack of the medicine; and (B) a statement is included on whichever label on the container, or the primary pack, or both, that does not set out the directions for use itself, that those directions are set out in the package insert; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a sunscreen preparation medicine has a label that does not have enough space to include the full directions for use, and the directions are instead provided in a package insert, what statement must be included on the label according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include a statement that the directions for use are set out in the package insert.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(ii)(B) states that if there is insufficient space on the label to include directions for use, and the directions are set out in a package insert, then a statement must be included on the label indicating that the directions are in the package insert.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Given a sunscreen preparation medicine whose dose is typically determined for each patient by an authorized health professional, is the medicine's label required to include directions for use based on the information provided in the regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the label is not required to include directions for use in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(a) specifies that the medicine is a sunscreen preparation. Section 8(1)(l)(i) states that directions for use are not required on the label if the dose is usually determined for each patient by an authorized health professional. Therefore, the sunscreen preparation label does not need to include directions for use.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a sunscreen preparation medicine label lacks sufficient space for including directions for use. Assuming the primary pack contains a package insert with the full usage directions, does the regulation mandate that both the container label and primary pack label include a statement referring to the insert?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the regulation does not require both labels to include the statement referring to the package insert in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(a) establishes that the medicine is a sunscreen preparation. Section 8(1)(l)(ii) allows for directions for use to be omitted from the label if space is insufficient and they are instead provided in a package insert. Part (B) specifies that a statement referring to the insert must be included on 'whichever label on the container, or the primary pack, or both, that does not set out the directions for use itself.' This means only the label(s) lacking the full directions need the referral statement, not necessarily both.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a sunscreen preparation medicine, if the label has inadequate space for directions for use, they are instead provided in a package insert, and the primary pack label already has a statement referring to this insert, is it required that the container label also include an identical statement according to the regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, it is not required for the container label to also have the statement in this situation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(a) confirms the medicine is a sunscreen preparation. Section 8(1)(l)(ii) permits directions for use to be excluded from the label if space is insufficient, provided they are in a package insert instead. Subsection (B) states that a referral statement must be on 'whichever label on the container, or the primary pack, or both, that does not set out the directions for use itself.' Since the primary pack label already has this statement, the container label is not obligated to repeat it.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "critical health information" means information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) of this Order, that is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (b) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains the active ingredients acetaminophen and caffeine, and the label lists only acetaminophen as an active ingredient, does the label meet the requirements of the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(1)(b), the labels of a medicine must include the names of all active ingredients. Since the label only lists acetaminophen and omits caffeine, it does not meet the requirements specified in 8(1)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label omits the information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n), but includes all other required information, does the label comply with the definition of 'critical health information' in section 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines 'critical health information' as the information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n). Since the label omits all of this information, it does not comply with the definition of 'critical health information' provided in section 6, even though it includes the other required label information specified in section 8(1).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is self-selected by a consumer, and the label omits the name of one of the active ingredients, as required by 8(1)(b), can the label still contain the 'critical health information' as defined in section 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 states that for medicines self-selected by a consumer, the information required under 8(1)(b) is part of the 'critical health information'. 8(1)(b) requires the label to include the names of all active ingredients. Since the label omits the name of one active ingredient, it does not contain the 'critical health information' as defined in section 6 for self-selected medicines.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the label on a non-prescription medicine includes all required information except the name of one inactive ingredient, does the label meet the requirements of section 8(1), subject to the qualifications in 8(2), 8(3), 9 and 10?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(b) only requires the label to include the names of active ingredients, not inactive ingredients. The question states the label includes all other required information under 8(1). Therefore, even with one inactive ingredient omitted, the label meets the requirements of 8(1), subject to any additional qualifications specified in subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (c) if the medicine is: (i) supplied in either a small or a medium container; and (ii) contains multiple active ingredients then, in relation to compliance of the label with paragraph 9(3)(a), the names of the multiple active ingredients and their quantities may be presented together on a continuous line, or lines, of text.

9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (a) appear as a cohesive unit by the placing of the name and quantity of each active ingredient together on separate lines of text either (i) immediately below the name of the medicine; or (ii) where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured, adjacent to the name of the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains multiple active ingredients and is supplied in a small container, can the names and quantities of the active ingredients be presented together on a continuous line of text on the main label, while still complying with the requirement in 9(3)(a) for the name and quantity of each active ingredient to appear together on separate lines of text either immediately below or adjacent to the name of the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to 9(3)(c), if a medicine is supplied in a small or medium container and contains multiple active ingredients, then the names and quantities of the active ingredients may be presented together on a continuous line or lines of text, in relation to compliance with 9(3)(a). This means that the requirement in 9(3)(a) for the name and quantity of each active ingredient to appear together on separate lines either immediately below or adjacent to the name of the medicine does not apply in this case.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in a large container and contains multiple active ingredients, can the names and quantities of the active ingredients be presented together on a continuous line of text on the main label, while still complying with the requirement in 9(3)(a)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The exception in 9(3)(c) that allows the names and quantities of multiple active ingredients to be presented together on a continuous line only applies if the medicine is supplied in a small or medium container. For a medicine in a large container, the general requirement in 9(3)(a) would still apply, meaning the name and quantity of each active ingredient must appear together on separate lines of text either immediately below or adjacent to the name of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains a single active ingredient and is supplied in a small container, do the name and quantity of the active ingredient need to appear together on a separate line of text immediately below or adjacent to the name of the medicine on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The exception in 9(3)(c) only applies to medicines that contain multiple active ingredients. For a medicine with a single active ingredient, regardless of the container size, the requirement in 9(3)(a) applies. This means the name and quantity of the single active ingredient must appear together on a separate line of text either immediately below or adjacent to the name of the medicine on the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the trademark of a medicine might be disrupted or obscured if the name and quantity of the active ingredient appeared immediately below the name of the medicine on the main label, where should the name and quantity of the active ingredient be placed to comply with 9(3)(a)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Adjacent to the name of the medicine
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(3)(a)(ii) provides that where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured by placing the name and quantity of the active ingredient immediately below the name of the medicine, they may instead be placed adjacent to the name of the medicine. This allows compliance with the general requirement for the active ingredient name and quantity to appear together with the medicine name as a cohesive unit, without risking disruption to the medicine's trademark.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (c) where paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply- the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine

11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (a) where the medicine is a fully potentised, single ingredient, homoeopathic medicine and it is clear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine – the name of the active ingredient; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic medicine is a fully potentised, single ingredient preparation and it is clear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine, what information must the label on the container and primary pack include regarding the quantity or proportion of active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the active ingredient.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(3)(a), if a homoeopathic medicine is a fully potentised, single ingredient preparation and it is clear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine, the label on the container and primary pack must include the name of the active ingredient.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic medicine does not meet the criteria in sections 11(3)(a) and 11(3)(b), what information must the label on the container and primary pack include regarding the quantity or proportion of active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(3)(c), if a homoeopathic medicine does not meet the criteria in sections 11(3)(a) and 11(3)(b), the label on the container and primary pack must include the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label does not have space to include the directions for use on the container or primary pack label, what two conditions must be met in order to omit the directions from the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The directions for use can be omitted if: 1) They are provided in a package insert in the primary pack, and 2) The label that does not contain the directions includes a statement that the directions are in the package insert.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(ii) states that if there is insufficient space on the label to include directions, they can be omitted if: (A) the directions are set out in a package insert provided in the primary pack, and (B) a statement is included on the label without directions indicating they are in the package insert.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine's dose is usually determined for each patient by an authorized health professional, is it required to include directions for use on the medicine label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, directions for use are not required on the label in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(i) provides an exception to including directions for use on the label when the dose is usually determined for each individual patient by an authorized health professional.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label meets the space and packaging insert requirements to omit directions for use, is the information required by paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Order still considered 'critical health information' that must be on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the information required by paragraph 8(1)(b) is still considered 'critical health information' even if the directions for use are omitted from the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines 'critical health information' as including the information required under paragraph 8(1)(b). This is independent of the exceptions that allow omitting directions for use from the label under 8(1)(l).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine's dose is usually determined by an authorized health professional and the directions for use are omitted following section 8(1)(l)(i), is a package insert with directions for use still required to be provided in the primary pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, if the directions for use are omitted under the 8(1)(l)(i) exception for doses determined by a health professional, a package insert with directions is not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l) provides two independent exceptions allowing directions for use to be omitted. 8(1)(l)(i) for doses determined by a health professional does not require a package insert, while 8(1)(l)(ii) for insufficient label space requires a package insert with the directions.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (b) The critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the following order: (i) Active ingredients (ii) Indications (iii) Warnings (iv) Directions for use (v) Other information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label includes a section titled 'Storage Conditions', where would this section be placed according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Under the 'Other information' heading
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 8(2)(e), information about storage conditions must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b). Section 8(2)(b) specifies the order of critical health information headings.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the regulation, is it permissible for a medicine label to include a section titled 'Excipient List' directly after the 'Directions for use' section?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(b) states that the critical health information must be presented in a specific order, ending with 'Other information'. Section 8(2)(e) then specifies that any additional information, including excipient names, must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows the 8(2)(b) headings.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming no other regulation sections are relevant, can a medicine label include sponsor contact details under the 'Warnings' heading?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Based on sections 8(2)(b) and 8(2)(e), sponsor contact details cannot be included under the 'Warnings' heading. Section 8(2)(b) specifies the order of critical health information headings, with 'Warnings' coming before 'Other information'. Section 8(2)(e) states that sponsor contact details must be under 'Other information' or another appropriate heading after the 8(2)(b) headings.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Considering only the provided regulation sections, is information about package tamper-evident features allowed to be placed between the 'Indications' and 'Warnings' headings?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(b) mandates that the critical health information headings, including 'Indications' and 'Warnings', must be presented in the specified order without other information between them. Section 8(2)(e) requires information about tamper-evident packaging to be under 'Other information' or another heading after the 8(2)(b) headings.

9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (c) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a composite pack or medicine kit containing multiple formulations, and the medicine is intended to be registered goods, what information must be provided separately for each formulation according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately for each formulation of medicine in the composite pack or medicine kit.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(d) states that for a medicine that is a composite pack or medicine kit, the information required under 9(6)(b) or 9(7) must be provided separately for each formulation in the pack or kit. Section 9(7) specifies requirements for medicines intended to be registered goods.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine intended to be registered goods that contains four or more active ingredients, assuming subsection 8(2) applies, what labeling requirements are not required to be met according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required for a medicine intended to be registered goods that contains four or more active ingredients if subsection 8(2) applies.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(c) states that for a medicine intended to be registered goods containing four or more active ingredients, if subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. This is subject to the condition in 9(9).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a composite pack or medicine kit containing multiple formulations that are all intended to be registered goods, and each formulation contains four or more active ingredients with subsection 8(2) applying, what labeling requirements can be omitted for each formulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: For each formulation in the composite pack or medicine kit, the information required under 9(7) can omit compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c), provided subsection 8(2) applies to each formulation containing four or more active ingredients. The information under 9(7) must still be provided separately for each formulation as per 9(8)(d).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Combining 9(8)(d) and 9(7)(c), for a composite pack or kit, the labeling for each component formulation intended as registered goods with 4+ ingredients can omit 9(1)(b) and (c) if 8(2) applies, but the labeling required under 9(7) must still be provided separately for each formulation in the pack/kit.

QuestionAnswers.Question: In a composite pack or medicine kit containing multiple formulations, assuming one formulation is intended to be registered goods and contains five active ingredients with subsection 8(2) applying, while another formulation is not registered goods, what differing labeling requirements apply to each formulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The formulation intended as registered goods with five active ingredients can omit information required in 9(1)(b) and (c) since 8(2) applies, but must provide the information required under 9(7). The non-registered goods formulation must provide information under 9(6)(b) instead of 9(7). Per 9(8)(d), the applicable information must be provided separately for each formulation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(8)(d) requires relevant information to be separate for each formulation. For the registered goods, 9(7)(c) allows omitting 9(1)(b) and (c) as it has 5 ingredients and 8(2) applies, but other parts of 9(7) still apply. The non-registered formulation must follow 9(6)(b) instead of 9(7) per the distinction made in 9(8)(d).
